Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TM1-HN31-F03R-N2P2-00000-00Davis Polk Discusses the New Populist Movement in Antitrust2018-10-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisDavis Polk Discusses the New Populist Movement in AntitrustArthur Burke, Ronan Harty, Jon Leibowitz, Howard Shelanski and Jesse Solomon

Oct 30, 2018( CLS Blue Sky Blog: http://clsbluesky.law.columbia.edu Delivered by Newstex) In recent years, a new populist school of antitrust thinking has emerged, known as 'Neo-Brandeisian' to its proponents and 'hipster' to its detractors. There are varying formulations of this movement, but proponents generally point to the purported increase in economic concentration and corporate profits in the U.S. economy to advocate for more aggressive antitrust enforcement, with respect to both mergers and other conduct. One notable element of this movement is a push to expand or even replace the established 'consumer welfare' standard—which focuses on prices and outputs in balancing potential competitive harms against procompetitive efficiencies—by adopting a more rigid presumption that corporate 'bigness' and large market share in themselves harm consumers. Some proponents, moreover, advocate for consideration of nontraditional factors in antitrust analysis, such as wages, employment levels, or growing inequality.

Such approaches, which could significantly increase the burden on merging parties and allegedly dominant firms, have gained support from prominent figures on both the left and the right. Nevertheless, thus far, the new populism has not made notable inroads with antitrust practitioners, antitrust enforcement agencies, or the courts. The differences between long-standing practice and the new progressive antitrust proposals have come into sharp focus in recent weeks, taking center stage at the FTC's ongoing 'Hearings on Competition and Consumer Protection in the 21st Century.' Could populist antitrust proposals replace the established consumer welfare framework for antitrust analysis in the United States? Whether the new populist antitrust agenda will take hold depends on the extent to which it can persuade the antitrust enforcement agencies, Congress, and the courts—all of which are interrelated and influence one another—of its underlying evidence and policy prescriptions. Indeed, the willingness of one of these government institutions to advance or reject populist perspectives could affect how open the others will be to revising antitrust thinking. It is too early to tell whether any significant change will occur, or whether that change will reflect a fundamental departure from or just more aggressive enforcement within the existing framework. It is clear, however, that antitrust policy is in the midst of an important debate that could affect how antitrust agencies evaluate business conduct, potentially increasing burdens on merging parties, raising the likelihood of significant divestiture requirements, and limiting the business activities in which firms with large market share can engage. This client memorandum examines the core elements and growing influence of the progressive antitrust movement, reviews its possible acceptance by government institutions, and considers whether it could modify the consumer welfare standard as the framework for antitrust analysis in the U.S.IntroductionDebate over the appropriate standard for evaluating the competitive effects of business transactions and business conduct has long existed in the United States, with the dominant ideology shifting over time. Antitrust sentiment emerged during the Gilded Age of the 1880s in the midst of populist concern over growing corporate concentration and power, with both Democrats and Republicans rallying against the 'trusts' that had come to dominate commerce. During the Progressive Era that followed, Congress enacted the Sherman and Clayton Acts, and antitrust suits led to thebreakupof corporate entities that restrained trade and manipulated markets. Following the First World War, however, American hostility to big business began to fade and antitrust enforcement ebbed. By the 1960s, however, the pendulum had swung back to aggressive antitrust enforcement, especially against mergers. The leading perspective at the time was that consolidation was inherently bad and that efficiency provided scant justification in competition reviews. This thinking allowed the antitrust agencies to block mergers without putting forward much evidence that the mergers were likely to harm competition. For example, during this era the Supreme Court held that the merger of the 10th and 18th largest beer brewers in the U.S. (resulting in a combined national share of 4.49% and no higher than 24% in any state) was a violation of the merger laws in light of 'a history of concentration in the beer industry.'[1][1] In response to numerous enforcement actions that blocked business activities that would likely have benefited consumers, a new approach to antitrust thinking rose to prominence in the 1970s and 1980s. Known as the 'Chicago School' because of its origin among economists and lawyers at the University of Chicago, this school of thought called for a greater emphasis on benefits to consumers and more rigorous economic analysis. It endorsed a 'consumer welfare' standard for antitrust reviews, which balances an activity's potential harm to consumers—generally experienced through higher prices, lower output, decreased quality, less choice, or reduced innovation—against procompetitive benefits such as lower prices, greater choice, or increased innovation.[2][2] Over time the consumer welfare standard, with its emphasis on economic benefits over structural presumptions, ultimately became the dominant approach, and it continues as the prevailing standard today, even as other elements of the Chicago School's economic approach have been challenged from time to time. Today's emerging antitrust populism movement is a reaction to this post-Chicago status quo, which the movement criticizes as having resulted in under-enforcement, industry concentration, and greater wealth inequality. Accordingly, rather than emphasizing 'consumer welfare,' measured by price and output levels, this loose-knit coalition promotes the incorporation of factors currently not included in antitrust analysis. These factors include loss of employment, increase in political influence, economic inequality, and impact on startup companies. Advocates point to the uneven recovery following the Great Recession as another catalyst for this new populist thinking—arguing that while stock markets and M...ctivity have risen dramatically, ordinary Americans have been left behind. As in the 1880s, large corporations find themselves to be the populist antitrust movement's primary target. This movement, limited until recently to a few academics and advocacy groups, has garnered more mainstream attention from practitioners and government actors, particularly members of Congress.The Antitrust Enforcement AgenciesThe populist movement appears to have developed an audience, at least, with U.S. antitrust enforcement agencies, especially the Federal Trade Commission ('FTC'). Indeed, at the FTC's hearings on antitrust and consumer protection issues (which will run through January 2019), populist arguments have taken center stage during some sessions.[3][3] In his opening statement at the hearings, FTC Chairman Joseph Simons cited recent criticism of the consumer welfare standard as one of the primary challenges that the hearings were meant to address.[4][4] Thereafter, a variety of panelists cited corporate consolidation as a major driver of economic inequality and suggested that some proposals characterized as 'populist' may not be all that unreasonable.[5][5] Even before the hearings began, FTC Commissioner Rohit Chopra (one of the Commission's two Democratic members) published a comment letter proposing that the FTC use its rulemaking authority to 'bolster antitrust enforcement.'[6][6] In contrast, panelists at the second day of hearings generally leaned toward maintaining the status quo. While a few participants still made impassioned calls to scrutinize big companies more stringently (notably, Nobel-winning economist Joseph Stiglitz of Columbia University), panel discussions focused on practical steps for reform within the existing antitrust framework rather than adoption of new approaches. For instance, the panelists discussed more aggressive enforcement by agencies, the issuance of revised guidelines (e.g., vertical merger guidelines), the performance of industry-specific studies (e.g., on drug patents), and neglected facets of the consumer welfare standard (e.g., buy-side concentration, non-price effects, and encouraging innovative startups).[7][7] Panelists noted that the consumer welfare standard is flexible and can address an array of competitive harms, but that antitrust law is ill-suited to address broader policy concerns, such as inequality or unemployment. Such arguments regarding the appropriate criteria and presumptions for evaluating antitrust harm will likely resurface in future sessions—notably on panels that will discuss the competitive effects of mergers, measurement of market power and barriers to entry, and the interaction between large technology companies and antitrust. Perhaps most importantly, though the FTC's hearings entertained a diversity of viewpoints, President Trump's appointees to the FTC and the Department of Justice's Antitrust Division ('DOJ') have expressed support for established norms. While Chairman Simons has acknowledged criticisms levied against the consumer welfare standard, as Director of the FTC's Bureau of Competition (from 2001 to 2003), he took an economics-driven approach to enforcement and recognized the importance of procompetitive justifications.[8][8] Further, since he became chairman, Simons has made clear his view that 'basing antitrust policy and enforcement decisions on an ideological viewpoint (from either the left or the right) is a mistake.'[9][9] Perhaps more strongly, the head of the Antitrust Division, Makan Delrahim, stated that 'we don't need to go beyond the consumer welfare standard, because it can get the job done on its own' and that 'there are serious risks to democracy in abandoning the consumer welfare standard.'[10][10] Accordingly, we view it as unlikely that the current slate of antitrust enforcement officials will depart much from the consumer welfare standard, certainly not dramatically or immediately.CongressLegislation might present a more likely path for changing our current antitrust framework. Some Democrats have already outlined a plan to strengthen the antitrust laws in order to 'address excessive concentration' and end corporate 'abuse of economic power.'[11][11] A recent Democratic congressional platform, 'A Better Deal,' includes proposals that would appear to depart from the consumer welfare approach as well as otherwise toughening the antitrust laws. These proposals include: (1)requiring the antitrust agencies to consider whether mergers eliminate jobs or hinder the ability of small businesses to compete; (2)requiring post-merger reviews of companies to ensure that they are not harming competition (which could allow the imposition of post-closing remedies); (3)creating a 'consumer competition advocate'—independent of the antitrust enforcement agencies—that would recommend investigations; and (4)providing that 'the largest mergers would be presumed to be anticompetitive and would be blocked unless the merging firms could establish the benefits of the deal.'[12][12] To this end, Senate Democrats have already introduced several bills.[13][13] Most notably, the Consolidation Prevention and Competition Promotion Act of 2017 ('CPCPA') introduced by Amy Klobuchar (D-MN), the Ranking Democrat on the Antitrust Subcommittee, would amend Section 7 of the Clayton Act (the statute governing merger enforcement) to make it easier for the antitrust agencies to prohibit a transaction. The core of the proposal would lower the standard of proof for an agency to block a merger from a 'substantial' to a 'material' lessening of competition (although the practical difference is hard to pin down from the language itself). Another provision of the CPCPA, which would apply to targets worth more than $5 billion when the acquiring company has a market capitalization of at least $100 billion, would require the merging parties to prove that there is no 'material' lessening of competition. (The long-standing current standard puts the burden of proof on the antitrust agency.)[14][14] Relatedly, Senator Elizabeth Warren (D-MA) suggested requiring Amazon to divest all of its assets other than its e-commerce platform, much as banks were once required to do under the Glass-Steagall Act.[15][15] As a practical matter, if turned into law, these proposals would make it notably easier for the enforcement agencies to block transactions, particularly large ones—affecting many of the almost 2,000 transactions each year that parties report to the FTC and DOJ.[16][16] Transaction data suggest that in the first half of 2018 almost 20% of transactions were valued at over $5 billion,[17][17] while another source notes that there have been 243 announced transactions valued at over $5 billion in the past five years.[18][18] Just listing a few recent mergers with buyer market capitalization over $100 billion and targets valued at over $5 billion provides a glimpse of the potential impact the 'large merger' provision could have: Disney/21st Century Fox; UTC/Rockwell Collins; Amazon/Whole Foods; Dow/DuPont; and AT...ime Warner. In addition to these merger-related impacts, under the various proposed measures, companies run the risk of triggering heightened antitrust consequences as they cross certain size thresholds, even if purely through successful competition on the merits of their products and services. Some Republicans, most notably Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) and President Trump, have also adopted populist antitrust rhetoric. A former Director of the FTC's Office of Policy Planning, Senator Cruz has suggested using the antitrust laws to curtail the position of large technology platforms.[19][19] President Trump has often made public statements that echo populist antitrust rhetoric. While on the campaign trail, he pledged to block the AT...ime Warner transaction, stating that it would concentrate too much 'power in the hands of too few.'[20][20] He also promised to break up companies that he considered to be too large and to have too much political influence. More recently, the White House has reportedly drafted an Executive Order that calls for the antitrust agencies to probe leading tech companies for alleged 'antitrust' violations relating to a perceived bias against conservatives on online platforms.[21][21] As of the date of this Client Memorandum, the Executive Order has not been publicly released. While these legislative proposals and supportive rhetoric should give companies pause, there has so far been nothing close to a clarion call or imminent consensus for competition law reform in Congress. Though statements like those from Senator Cruz might suggest bipartisan interest in antitrust reform, a notably different take comes from Senator Orrin Hatch (R-UT): commenting on the Democrats' 'A Better Deal' platform, Hatch, stated that this 'peculiarset of proposals' leaves him 'deeply unimpressed.'[22][22] The silence on the issue from most legislators on both sides of the aisle does not suggest antitrust reform at this time has much momentum. But the Congress next year may have a different calculation.The JudiciaryThe judiciary has historically played arguably the most critical role in antitrust enforcement, interpreting the vast delegations of authority given to it under the antitrust laws as well as reviewing cases brought by the agencies and private parties. Indeed, the Supreme Court has noted that antitrust is, perhaps uniquely, a form of federal common law because of its largely court-driven evolution. Notably, in recent years the Supreme Court has repeatedly taken positions making antitrust enforcement more difficult, holding that antitrust laws do not limit certain types of conduct and rejecting efforts to minimize plaintiffs' burdens of proof. For example, in 2004 the Supreme Court in Trinko (and again in 2009, in Credit Suisse) placed important limits on antitrust intervention in regulated sectors of the economy. The Trinko Court also warned about the overextension of antitrust intervention, noting that 'The Sherman Actdoes not give judges carte blanche to insist that a monopolist alter its way of doing business whenever some other approach may yield greater competition.'[23][23] Moreover, just last term the Supreme Court ruled in Ohio v. American Express that plaintiffs bear a particularly high burden when proving anticompetitive effects in two-sided markets when there are 'pronounced indirect network effects and interconnected pricing and demand.'[24][24] Courts must balance the benefits that the platform's actions bring to one side of the platform against any potential harm to the other side. The practical effect of this decision is that it becomes more difficult for a plaintiff to establish an antitrust violation, which could have a notable impact in the growing technology sector of the economy.[25][25] The Supreme Court's conservative/centrist bent in antitrust cases is likely to strengthen with the addition of Justice Kavanaugh, and even sitting 'liberal' Justices Breyer and Kagan have expressed support for the existing 'consumer welfare' standard.[26][26] Lower courts have also resisted changes to the consumer welfare approach and to the economic methods used to assess conduct under that standard, as exemplified this summer when the D.C. District Court rejected the DOJ's effort to block the AT...ime Warner transaction. AT...ime Warner involved a rare agency challenge to a vertical merger, and in his opinion, Judge Leon emphasized that the vertical merger would result in savings and no elimination of competition.[27][27] The case is on appeal to the D.C. Circuit, with a decision likely in early 2019. Should the case end up before the Supreme Court, it would be the first merger case before the Court in several decades. Accordingly, it seems unlikely that populist antitrust proposals will take hold through judicial intervention in the foreseeable future.[28][28]ConclusionThe conflict between emerging populist antitrust ideas and the established consumer welfare standard has become a central topic in the press, among lawmakers, and at the ongoing FTC Hearings on Competition and Consumer Protection in the 21st Century. Whether the outcome of these hearings leads to a new consensus in antitrust thinking or leaves the current standard intact is unclear, although, as we have stated, we do not think significant change is imminent through the agencies, Congress, or the courts. Nonetheless, this unfolding debate and the responses of government institutions warrant continuing attention, given the potential stakes for enterprises doing business in the United States. ENDNOTES [1][29] U.S. v. Pabst Brewing Co., 384 U.S. 546, 546 (1966); see also U.S. v. Vons Grocery Co., 384 U.S. 270 (1966) (blocking the merger of two grocery store chains in the Los Angeles area with a combined 7.5% of sales at the time of the merger in light of the stores' growth in the preceding decade and perceived increasing concentration). [2][30] There are still some antitrust matters that are per se illegal, without any balancing of potential harms and benefits once the conduct is proven, such as collusion between competitors ('price-fixing') and members of the board of directors of one company sitting on the board of a competitor ('interlocking directorates'). [3][31] New York Times, F.T.C. Hearings Add to Efforts That Threaten Tech Industry[32] (Sept. 13, 2018) (quoting FTC Chairman Joseph Simons in discussing concerns over large tech companies as stating '[t]hese concerns raise a challenge to antirust agency leadership, the courts and legislature'). Multiple other bills have also recently been introduced that would impact antitrust, particularly merger, enforcement. In May 2018, the House passed the SMARTER Act (which lowers the FTC's burden to block a transaction in order to match the DOJ standard); the SMARTER Act is still pending in the Senate. The Food and Agribusiness Merger Moratorium and Antitrust Review Act of 2018 would impose a moratorium on large agribusiness, food and beverage manufacturing, and grocery retail mergers and would establish a commission to review competition issues in those industries. The Journalism Competition and Preservation Act of 2018 would temporarily exempt small news publications from the antitrust laws in order to give them negotiating leverage against the 'duopoly' of Google and Facebook in online advertising. For example, the Department of Justice and several state attorneys general have recently begun to focus on technology companies, in part out of concern that these companies are using their market positions to bury conservative views. John D. McKinnon, More States to Join Justice Department's Discussion of Social Media Companies[68], Wall Street Journal (Sept. 14, 2018); Mark Ballard, Louisiana AG Jeff Landry wants to break up social media giants[69], Advocate (Sept. 18, 2018); see also Steve Hilton, Positive Populism (2018) (proposing that conservatives should embrace the legacy of Republican trust-busters like President Teddy Roosevelt and Senator John Sherman (R-OH) and confront the market power of big tech by imposing regulation, and proposing that companies with higher market shares pay higher taxes). [22][70] Floor Remarks, Aug. 3, 2017 (as reported by Wired, Do Not Mistake Orrin Hatch for #HipsterAntitrust[71] (Aug. 3, 2017)). [23][72] Verizon Commn'cs Inc. v. Law Offices of Curtis V. As described in this memorandum, two-sided platforms (like Amazon and Facebook) are increasingly the subject of political backlash. [26][75] In FTC v. Actavis (2013), the Court rejected the FTC's attempt to make reverse payment settlement agreements presumptively unlawful, forcing the FTC to 'prove its case' under a more difficult 'rule of reason' standard. [27][76] U.S. v. AT...nc., 310 F. Supp. 3d 161, 164 (D.D.C. 2018). [28][77] But, of course, the same was initially believed about the Chicago School's replacement of the previous structural approach. This post comes to us from Davis, Polk ...rdwell LLP. value.Byline: By Tom Rees and Lucy Burton and Gordon Rayner, Political Editor
value.Title: Davos 2018: Donald Trump to visit UK by the end of the year
value.Overview: telegraph.co.uk, BUSINESS; Version:37, 7805words

Extracts.SummaryText: ... The UK and Brexit negotiations take centre stage on day three in the Alps with Chancellor Philip Hammond speaking on artificial intelligence this morning before meeting with British business leaders and Prime Minister Theresa May delivering today's most anticipated speech this afternoon. Good morning from #Davos . On day3 of #WEF18 UK's PM Theresa May in the spotlight. No dedicated Brexit speech, she will take Big Tech to task. Besides that, Dollar stance of US Admin will in focus in panel w/Mnuchin, ...

urn:contentItem:5RGR-MHV1-F021-6028-00000-00Davos 2018: Donald Trump to visit UK by the end of the year2018-01-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisBUSINESSVersion:37Davos 2018: Donald Trump to visit UK by the end of the year By Tom Rees and Lucy Burton and Gordon Rayner, Political Editor

President Donald Trump has confirmed his visit to Britain is back on for this year as he insisted that talk of a rift with Theresa May was a "false rumour". The President said he had a "great relationship" with Mrs May and that trade would "increase many times" after Brexit.

Earlier this month the President cancelled a planned visit to open the US Embassy in London, prompting speculation that he was riled by a rebuke from Mrs May over his apparent support of a right-wing group.

Mr Trump is also said to be concerned that he will face ugly protests in the capital after Labour MPs and London Mayor Sadiq Khan made it clear he was not welcome.

But as Mr Trump held a one-to-one meeting with Mrs May in Davos, he insisted he will make a visit in 2018, adding: "We love your country."

Mrs May was one of the first world leaders to meet Mr Trump after he arrived at the World Economic Forum at the Swiss ski resort, and discussed topics ranging from Iran and Syria to the US trade levy on Ulster-made Bombardier aircraft wings.

Mr Trump said: "We've had a great discussion - we're on the same wavelength, I think, in every respect. And the Prime Minister and myself have had a really great relationship, although some people don't necessary believe that, but I can tell you it's true. "I have tremendous respect for the Prime Minister and the job she's doing. And I think the feeling is mutual from the standpoint of liking each other a lot.

"And uh, so it was a little bit of a false rumour out there, I just wanted to correct it, frankly, because we have great respect for everything you're doing and we love your country. We think it's really great, and we are working on transactions in terms of economic development, trade, maybe most importantly military."

A senior Government source said Mr Trump was expected to visit in the second half of this year and "it's clear that the President wants to come". 

7:24PM Here's a reminder of the key moments from today

Eager to build bridges with Britain, Donald Trump waxed lyrical about Theresa May ahead of their meeting - claiming that the pair are "on the same wavelength" with rumours of any rift "false" as he "likes her a lot". 

He predicted a "tremendous" increase in trade between the UK and US, with Theresa May returning the warm words by saying that the UK's special relationship with the US is "as strong as ever". Number 10 then confirmed that Trump would be visiting the UK later this year - weeks after he cancelled his trip to Britain because the US embassy's move from Mayfair to the  south of the Thames  was a "bad deal".

Delegates seemed largely unmoved by Theresa May's speech, The Telegraph's Tim Wallace reported from Davos, although she won some praise for touching on themes of internet security. "Why didn't she talk about Brexit?" one Japanese delegate asked. 

Speaking of which, Chancellor  Philip Hammond called for a soft Brexit  with only "very modest" changes to Britain's relationship with the EU just moments earlier. 

He said: "We are taking two completely interconnected and aligned economies with high levels of trade and selectively moving them, hopefully very modestly apart." 

The dollar sell-off intensified on currency markets today as US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin refused to budge on his currency-weakening comments at Davos. 

In the evening, billionaire investor George Soros criticised Facebook and Google and said they had "become obstacles to innovation". 

7:02PM HSBC chairman Mark Tucker among guests at Trump dinner

Here's who's having dinner with Trump at Davos https://t.co/pHvTx1Rtgvpic.twitter.com/NGlM2iLGrs

- Bloomberg (@business) January 25, 2018 6:43PM White House issues statement on Trump's "working visit" to Britain in the coming months

NEW: Pres. Trump, UK Prime Minister Theresa May "discussed plans for a working visit to London in the coming months" at World Economic Forum in Davos, White House says. pic.twitter.com/WHNz07MLUI

- ABC News Politics (@ABCPolitics) January 25, 2018 6:32PM Dollar sell-off intensified on currency markets

The dollar sell-off intensified on currency markets today as US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin refused to budge on his currency-weakening comments at Davos, helping sterling extend its rally against the greenback above $1.43.  

Mr Mnuchin insisted that he was not concerned about where the dollar was in the short-term with its plunge against the euro worsened by ECB President Mario Draghi's rising confidence in inflation meeting the central bank's 2pc target.

Although the pound's gains cooled during the afternoon, a fourth day pushing higher against the dollar sent London's heavyweight exporters tumbling. The FTSE 100's huge dollar earners continued to suffer with the wider index slipping 0.4pc to 7,615.84 points.

This week's 2.9pc surge leaves sterling on course for its best weekly rise against the dollar in just over seven years with traders now eyeing Donald Trump's hotly anticipated speech at the World Economic Forum tomorrow. 

6:20PM Theresa May suffers ultimate put-down in Davos

Theresa May suffered the ultimate put-down in Davos after her underwhelming speech, writesAmbrose Evans-Pritchardin Davos.  

The Dutch premier Mark Rutte said wearily that is up to her to decide what relationship she wants to have with Europe.

"We cannot have a situation where we have to decide for her," he said in a tone of voice that seemed to suggest that she is viewed as vacillating and vanishing, rather that strong and stable.

Mr Rutte added that David Cameron secured an "excellent package" from the EU before the Brexit vote.

This was not what he told a group of journalists in The Hague privately. The Telegraph understands that he said David Cameron "did not try hard enough".

For good measure, Mr Rutte said in Davos that southern and east European states that don't do what they are told by the EU should be "forced" to behave better, and should lose their farming and cohesion funds.

The Portuguese and Irish prime ministers on the panel with him bit their tongues.  

5:47PM Donald Trump has tweeted about his "great" meeting with Theresa May

Great bilateral meeting with Prime Minister Theresa May of the United Kingdom, affirming the special relationship and our commitment to work together on key national security challenges and economic opportunities. #WEF18pic.twitter.com/FPP8aRDAyt

- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 25, 2018

Following warm words from May....

"We continue to have that special relationship between the UK and the United States, standing shoulder-to-shoulder because we're facing the same challenges across the world, and working together for a good trade relationship in the future." - PM with President Trump at #Davos18pic.twitter.com/cqSgcLcoqd

- UK Prime Minister (@Number10gov) January 25, 2018 4:35PM Downing Street confirms Donald Trump will visit the UK "later this year" 

#Breaking Theresa May and Donald Trump have asked officials to work on "finalising the details of a visit by the President to the UK later this year", Downing Street says pic.twitter.com/UBfAm6fLie

- Press Association (@PA) January 25, 2018

Number 10 confirmed after the two leaders met in Davos on Thursday that officials on both sides will finalise the details of Trump's visit to the UK this year. 

Mr Trump cancelled his visit to Britain earlier this month, writing on Twitter that the US  embassy's move from Grosvenor Square  in Mayfair to Nine Elms, south of the Thames, was a "bad deal". 

Reason I canceled my trip to London is that I am not a big fan of the Obama Administration having sold perhaps the best located and finest embassy in London for "peanuts," only to build a new one in an off location for 1.2 billion dollars. Bad deal. Wanted me to cut ribbon-NO!

- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 12, 2018 4:02PM 'Good inflation' could be on the way with pay hikes in the US, says Mnuchin

Inflation could be back as the tax cuts in the US should feed into a spike in wage growth, according to Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, potentially shifting the country out of its recent pattern of strong growth with low inflation. 

Economists and market analysts fear that an unexpected rise in inflation would force the Federal Reserve to raise rates more quickly, putting both the stock market and the wider economy in peril.

But Mr Mnuchin said this is "good inflation" which should provide a boost for living standards and the economy.

He predicts the average family's wages will rise by $4,000, particularly because the tax rate for small and mid-sized companies is falling.

"This is the engine of growth, that is something which has been a great focus and we fundamentally believe that in excess of 70pc of the cost of business taxes is passed on to the worker," said the Treasury Secretary.

"This is about creating wage increases for workers, and that type of inflation is something we would consider to be good inflation and something we are comfortable with."

Several million workers are already in line to benefit, he told an event at the World Economic Forum in Davos ahead of Donald Trump's arrival.

Reporting by Tim Wallace in Davos.

3:37PM Theresa May speech wins muted response from Davos delegates

The Telegraph's Tim Wallace reports from Davos: 

The delegates seem largely underwhelmed with Theresa May's speech. Although she won some praise for touching on themes of internet security and stopping illegal material spreading through social media, the overall reaction was distinctly muted.

"It was pretty solid, but she just doesn't have the personality," said one observer from the US.

Another agreed: "If someone else had said exactly the same thing..." they left the thought hanging.

And the biggest complaint of all came from a Japanese delegate: "Why didn't she talk about Brexit?"

3:24PM Donald Trump meets Benjamin Netanyahu, accuses Palestine of 'disrespecting' Vice President Mike Pence

The US President and Israel's Prime Minister have met in Davos. 

The pair convened in the same room where Mr Trump had met Theresa May and they were joined by a number of the President's prominent aides including Jared Kushner, Rex Tillerson and H.R. McMaster. 

Mr Trump is believed to have told Mr Netanyahu that more money could be withheld from the Palestinians if they do not commit to peace talks. 

The US President said "they disrespected our great Vice President" in a reference to the apparent refusal of Mahmoud Abbas, the president of the Palestinian National Authority, to meet with Mike Pence during a recent trip to the Middle East.

The meeting comes just a matter of weeks after Mr Trump declared America would move its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. 

The decision represented a major boost to Israel's claim on the contested city but it sparked protests around the Muslim world, which turned violent in the Palestinian territories and led to the deaths of several demonstrators.

The Palestinians see east Jerusalem as the capital of any future state.

Mr Trump told Mr Netanyahu during the meeting that Israel "will pay" for receiving the concession on Jerusalem.

3:07PM Donald Trump dismisses reports of rift with Theresa May as 'false rumour' 3:02PM Davos: It was a "false rumour" that me and Theresa May don't get on, says Trump

Pres. Trump says he and Theresa May "are on the same wavelength in every respect." That may not help May back home. pic.twitter.com/LfTlNGDLIJ

- Evan McMurry (@evanmcmurry) January 25, 2018

Donald Trump has dismissed a "false rumour" that he and Theresa May have a difficult relationship, telling reporters that he "likes her a lot".

He refused to say when a state visit would be rescheduled after Mrs May told Bloomberg this morning that a visit would be arranged "in due course".

2:51PM Davos: There is nothing that would happen to you where we "wouldn't be there to fight for you", insists Trump

On meeting Theresa May this afternoon, Donald Trump claimed that the US and UK were "joined at the hip" in their military operations, adding that there was "nothing that would happen to you (where) we wouldn't be there to fight for you".

The two leaders attempted to dispel reports that they don't see eye to eye with Trump insisting they have a "really great relationship, although some people don't necessarily believe that".

2:33PM Davos: Theresa May and I are on the same wavelength, says Trump

US president Donald Trump has been waxing lyrical about Prime Minister Theresa May ahead of their meeting this afternoon, claiming that the two leaders are "on the same wavelength".

He added that trade discussions will lead to "tremendous" increases in trade between the UK and US.

This morning, the Prime Minister said that the UK's special relationship with the US is "as strong as ever" and that Mr Trump will visit the UK "in due course".

2:02PM Davos: Theresa May failed to rise to the challenge on Brexit

Our Associate Editor Jeremy Warnerhas just sent in his snap reaction to Theresa May's speech from on the ground in Davos.

A "familiar lack of charisma" and the conspicuous absence of the 'B' word let down the Prime Minister's speech, he said.

Theresa May has just finished speaking at Davos. First impressions? This was a worthy speech which was very characteristic of May's "on the one hand this, on the other hand that" style, but it also failed to capture the zeitgeist in an age of Trump, and it was delivered with a familiar lack of charisma.

If delegates had turned up to hear about Brexit, they would have been disappointed. She barely mentioned it, and she failed to rise to the challenge set by Professor Klaus Schwab, the World Economic Forum's president, to explain what the UK is trying to achieve.

Rather, she spoke mainly about technology and the challenges of artificial intelligence - big themes here at Davos. To be fair, she wasn't bad on the need to harness the opportunities, and extolling the UK's leading role in AI.

But she then drifted into a somewhat off message ramble on how best to regulate it, and through government intervention ensure that it was a force for good rather than hate speech, terrorist propaganda and the like. She also devoted much time to how technology must be harnessed to help the "left behinds".

Don't get me wrong. These are important issues, but they somehow didn't hit the spot. What Mrs May should be doing is selling Britain and Brexit to the world, much as Trump promises to sell his America First agenda to Davos tomorrow. In this respect she fell short. Roll on the new leader.

1:56PM Davos: Trump's bombastic delegation overshadows May

Theresa May hasn't quite matched the bombastic approach of Trump's team and one would imagine that her relatively tame appearance will be completely overshadowed by the US President, who is expected to ramp up his delegation's tough talk on trade tomorrow.

Speaking of, Tim Wallacehas battled through the crowd of cameras to get this snap of the President ahead of his meeting with Mrs May.

He hasn't thrown the cat among the pigeons just yet. Tim reported that he said he is very happy to be at Davos.

It will be anything but dull, that's for sure.

1:49PM Davos: A 'decent smattering' for May's speech

Did Mrs May draw in the crowds at Davos?

Tim Wallace, our reporter watching the speech at the World Economic Forum, sent over these few thoughts and pictures.

There is a reasonable turnout for Theresa May's speech in Davos - the first 15 rows or so are full. Even the back half of the hall, which is partially roped off in an effort to push delegates closer to the stage, has a decent smattering of attendees.

1:31PM Theresa May urges world leaders to work together to deliver economic growth that works for all

The Prime Minister finishes her speech in Davos by telling delegates that the UK has a "proud history" of leading technological change and delivering "progress for all". 

She says the UK stands "ready to do so again" as she urges world leaders to "renew our commitment to cooperation".

"Let us set ourselves on a path to deliver prosperity and growth for the benefit of all of our people now and for generations to come," she says.  

1:26PM Theresa May urges investors to consider social impact of new technology companies

The Prime Minister tells the World Economic Forum that "investors can play a vital role" in making the internet a better place "by considering the social impact of the companies they are investing in".

She says: "They can use their influence to ensure these issues are taken seriously.

"For example, earlier this month a group of shareholders demanded that Facebook and Twitter disclose more information about sexual harassment, fake news, hate speech and other forms of abuse that take place on the companies' platforms.

"Investors can make a big difference here by ensuring trust and safety issues are being properly considered. And I urge them to do so."

1:23PM Theresa May: Online extremist material should be removed automatically

The Prime Minister says the Government is working to make the UK the "safest place to be online". But she warns that cross-border cooperation is needed to tackle online threats.

She says: "Companies simply cannot stand by while their platforms are used to facilitate child abuse, modern slavery or the spreading of terrorist and extremist content.

"We have made some progress. Last September at the UN, I joined President Macron and Prime Minister Gentiloni in convening the first ever UN summit of government and industry to move further and faster in reducing the time it takes to remove terrorist content online, and to increase significantly their efforts to stop it being uploaded in the first place.

"But we need to go further, so that ultimately this content is removed automatically. These companies have some of the best brains in the world. They must focus their brightest and best on meeting these fundamental social responsibilities."

1:18PM Theresa May: We are only seeing the beginning of what artificial intelligence can achieve

Mrs May is setting out what the Government is doing to ensure that the UK is on the "front foot" when it comes to developing artificial intelligence technology. 

"We are only seeing the beginning of what AI can achieve," she says. 

Mrs May suggests the technology could make roads and other infrastructure safer and also help in the prevention of the spread of diseases. 

"These are the type of advances we could see and we should want to see," she says. 

1:14PM Theresa May: Working people have 'profound concerns' about threat to jobs posed by new technology

Mrs May says technological advances present the world with "new and profound challenges which we need to address" . 

She says many people fear that they will lose out "on the jobs of the future" because of the rise of automation and artificial intelligence.

She says they have "profound concerns" about what new technology could mean for them and their families but she stresses that with the correct oversight technology can be a "force for progress".

1:09PM Theresa May: Rhetoric in support of free trade 'not matched by action'

The Prime Minister has now started her speech in Davos. 

She says that since she addressed the World Economic Forum last year when she warned that economic growth and free trade was not working for everyone there has been progress made. 

However, she adds: "There is much more to be done by the whole international community and frankly our rhetoric in support of free trade here in Davos is not matched by action." 

Mrs May praises the ability of technology to lift people out of poverty but insists that "international frameworks" must be put in place to help facilitate that.  

1:05PM Theresa May: Special relationship with US 'strong as it ever has been'

Speaking ahead of her meeting with Donald Trump this afternoon, the Prime Minister has reiterated the UK's commitment to the special relationship with the US. 

The Prime Minister also stressed both the UK and US are "keen" to do a free trade deal after Brexit and are already working on the "shape" of an agreement.

Mrs May will meet Mr Trump for the first time since they clashed over the US president's retweeting of anti-Muslim videos posted by UK-based far-right group Britain First.

Ahead of their meeting, the PM said Mr Trump would visit the UK "in due course".

Speaking to the BBC, she said: "That relationship between the UK and America is strong as it ever has been.

"What I want to be talking to the president about and will be talking to him about is a whole range of foreign policy areas where we face shared challenges and are working together."

12:49PM Theresa May set to apply renewed pressure to social media companies 

The Prime Minister is due to deliver her speech in Davos at 1pm and she is expected to take aim at online companies to urge them to do more to tackle terror.

Mrs May is expected to call on social media companies to stop providing a platform for terror, extremism and child abuse.

The Prime Minister is also likely to urge investors to consider the social impact of the tech firms they invest in.

She will also set out the Government's aim to make the UK the world leader in the development of artificial intelligence technology.

12:43PM Davos: IMF and US fight over trade rules

Any new trade restrictions risk undermining the entire global economic recovery, Christine Lagarde said today in a thinly veiled swipe at Donald Trump's protectionism.

The head of the International Monetary Fund set out firm opposition to tariffs and other trade controls, arguing that growing investment and cross-border trade is now the engine of the long-awaited global recovery and should not be put at risk.

"International trade [is] growing even faster than global growth rates. Any measure that would try to slow down trade, that would try to limit the strength of this engine would be of concern," she told an event at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

"Not everything is perfect at the moment, but any measures which would restrict trade would hurt growth."

Ms Lagarde was sitting next to US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, and although she did not mention the US by name, he took the chance to defend American trade policies.

"Christine and I share very similar views on this - our issue is that we want more trade, not that we want less trade," he said.

Report byTim Wallace

12:28PM Davos: Hammond lightens the mood at lunch with UK business leaders

Chancellor Philip Hammond is currently schmoozing British business leaders at a lunch in Davos and has decided to dispel any tension with his audience by cracking a few jokes.

Our Executive Business EditorBen Marlow, who is sitting in on the lunch, sent back these one-liners from Spreadsheet Phil:

"As we came into Davos there was an avalanche warning yet the foreign secretary isn't even here. 

"I'm told a walk in the mountain air was what encouraged the PM to call the general election last year so I'm hoping she stays indoors this time."

Ben added that Mr Hammond reiterated that the UK will be leaving the EU on March 29 2019 and that decision will not be reversed.

12:14PM Davos: Will Trump start a trade war?

Tough trade war talk from Donald Trump's delegation has dominated the headlines from Davos in the last few days and the President himself has just touched down in the Alps ahead of his speech tomorrow.

Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross was ramping up the rhetoric yesterday, claiming that a trade war is already being waged and that US would soon be bringing the heavy artillery.

Will Trump start a trade war?

 Dr Fragkiskos Filippaios from the University of Kent gave his two cents:

"This is not the first time a Republican president introduces trade barriers. George Bush in the early 2000s introduced tariffs on the imports of steel. The matter was raised from other countries to WTO and the ruling of the international organisation led to the immediate withdrawal of the measures.

"It is highly likely that this is going to be the outcome in the washing machines and solar products case. Donald Trump will have gained brownie points internally by fulfilling his promise to put "America First" but at the same time will put the blame on WTO and its rulings for not being able to maintain the trade restrictions."

It appears Piers Morgan has bagged a few minutes with the man himself. Here he is looking serious and doing his power stance.

First clips from my world exclusive interview with President Trump will air on @GMB from 6am tomorrow morning. #davos#trumppic.twitter.com/0lEmyqV2fe

- Piers Morgan (@piersmorgan) January 25, 2018 12:03PM Trump arrives in Davos for WEF 11:45AM Davos: Theresa May set to urge tech giants to help in the fight against terror

Prime Minister Theresa May is expected to ramp up the pressure on Silicon Valley giants and urge them to help combat terrorism.

According to the BBC, she will urge big businesses to consider the social impact they are having on the world, arguing that social networks should not provide a platform for child abuse and extremist views. 

Chancellor Philip Hammond also attacked tech giants this morning for taking control of personal data through lengthy terms and conditions.

11:23AM Davos: IMF will upgrade gloomy growth forecast, insists Hammond

Chancellor Philip Hammond says financial services will be at the heart of our #Brexit negotiations #Davos2018pic.twitter.com/hlf8PP3Ltr

- Sally Bundock (@SallyBundockBBC) January 25, 2018

Chancellor Philip Hammond expects the International Monetary Fund to upgrade its gloomy growth predictions for the UK as details from the Brexit deal are fleshed out.

He also predicted at a panel discussion in Davos that inflation, which climbed to a peak of 3.1pc in November, will ease in 2018 and has already hit its highest level.

The IMF forecast growth of just 1.5pc in 2018 on the eve of the World Economic Forum in Davos while upgrading global growth to 3.9pc, its fastest rate in seven years.

11:04AM Davos: UK business bosses frustrated with lack of Brexit plan

Barclays boss Jes Staley insisted this morning that the Government was listening to the concerns of the City during Brexit negotiations but Ben Marlow has been hearing something quite different from business leaders in Davos. He sent back this report:

Much talk about continued disillusionment with Brexit among British bosses, but a different sort of frustration to the one that prevailed in the months after the vote. 

One I spoke to said people have moved on from whether it is right to leave the EU to what the plan is and there still doesn't appear to be one. That's what the big concern is. People have accepted we are leaving but they want to know how we are going to do it and why we still don't know.

Chancellor Philip Hammond will be meeting with UK bosses in Davos this lunchtime. It could be a frosty affair. 

10:52AM Davos: We need to look 'very seriously' at Bitcoin, says Theresa May

Theresa May backs Philip Hammond on regulating Bitcoin/cryptocurrencies. "We should be looking at these very seriously precisely because of the way they can be used, particularly by criminals," she tells Bloomberg in Davos.

- Jack Maidment (@jrmaidment) January 25, 2018

The UK and other governments should be looking "very seriously" at cryptocurrencies, Theresa May has warned ahead of her speech at Davos this afternoon,

In an interview with Bloomberg, she reinforced her Chancellor's urge of caution on digital currencies, saying that they can be used by criminal purposes.

Bitcoin's rapid rise has attracted the attention of regulators across the world with the cryptocurrency market spooked in recent weeks by authorities in South Korea, Japan and Russia threatening to crack down on Bitcoin trading.

10:46AM Davos: 'Thanks very much Steve', Hammond says to US Treasury Secretary for pound's climb against the dollar

Mnuchin says a weaker dollar benefits the U.S. economy as it "relates to trade and opportunities" #tictocnewshttps://t.co/R48zrXeOLmpic.twitter.com/4nkW72r4O3

- TicToc by Bloomberg (@tictoc) January 25, 2018

Our reporterTim Wallace is sitting in on an A-list panel discussion, featuring Chancellor Philip Hammond, IMF head Christine Lagarde and US Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin, and sent back these key quotes.

"Steve, thanks very much", Hammond said to Mnuchin for the pound's surge against the dollar this week to laughs from the Davos audience.

Mnuchin, who has sent the dollar sliding in the last few days with his endorsement of a weak currency, reiterated his view that the greenback being at a three-year low is "beneficial for our trade imbalances".

He added:

"Long term, I fundamentally believe in the strength of the dollar, it is the reserve currency and will continue to be the reserve currency, given the strength of US markets.

"Perhaps this is slightly different to previous Treasury secretaries who in recent times have just commented on strong dollar, strong dollar. I acknowledge that where the dollar is in the short term will be determined by the markets."

Mr Hammond isn't the only one getting a chuckle from a rather generous Davos audience.

Paul Achleitner, chairman of Deutsche  Bank's supervisory board, also got some laughs with this witty line:

"Thank you for inviting a bank onto this panel on remaking finance, and a European one at that - it indicates you believe European banks have a role in remaking finance, which isn't self-evident if one goes around Davos asking people."

10:29AM Davos: Presidents Club scandal would be 'unthinkable' in New York

Our Executive Business EditorBen Marlow has been down on the ground in Davos mingling with the great and the good and sent in this report on the reaction to the Presidents Club scandal grabbing the headlines back here in the UK.

Lots of talk about the Presidents Club expose as you would expect but very much a general feeling of incredulity among British chief execs out in Davos at those that were at the Presidents' Club. Questions about how in this day and age, people would still attend these sort of events, and that charity dinners like this still exist. 

One senior figure remarked that similar events would be unthinkable in New York, for example, so what does that say about the British business scene? Is it time for some genuine soul-searching on that front?

10:15AM Davos: Trump touches down in Zurich ahead of hotly anticipated speech

Donald Trump's team has been ruffling feathers at Davos all week but the man himself has just touched down in Zurich, Switzerland, ahead of his hotly anticipated speech tomorrow.

He looks a little uneasy about those stairs though...

Will soon be heading to Davos, Switzerland, to tell the world how great America is and is doing. Our economy is now booming and with all I am doing, will only get better...Our country is finally WINNING again!

- Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) January 25, 2018 10:08AM Davos: Gender equality comes to the fore at the World Economic Forum

Our economics correspondent Tim Wallaceis almost as busy as Philip Hammond this morning. Here are his latest snaps and pithy comments from Davos.

Gender equality is getting more attention at Davos this year. No sign of a pay equality lounge though.  

A busy day for Philip Hammond - here he is with Christine Lagarde and Steven Mnuchin talking about 'the remaking of global finance' 

After this he is going to the British Business lunch.

9:55AM Davos: Watch Malala Yousafzai speak on gender equality and education 9:54AM Hammond: We must not be Luddites on artificial intelligence

Artificial intelligence could create a new generation of Luddites as new technology takes jobs faster than workers can retrain for new careers, Philip Hammond has warned.

The Chancellor pledged to manage the impact of smart machines, seeking to get the benefits of faster economic growth while limiting the disruption to ordinary people's lives.

"For many, what people in this room see as an exciting challenge ahead, will seem like a big threat to their livelihoods and their prosperity, including many people in the professions and the middle classes who have been able to shrug off technological change in the past as something that affects others but will leave them immune," he told an event run by Microsoft at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

The positive impact on productivity and living standards "will be transformative", he said.

"It is said that artificial intelligence could double the rate of economic growth in advanced economies by 2035, and I am quite prepared to believe that is possible," Mr Hammond said.

"Let's not create a generation of 21st century Luddites who feel that their only chance for survival is to resist this change."

Report byTim Wallace

9:45AM Davos: Government has taken a 'keen interest' in the City during Brexit talks, says Barclays boss

Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Barclays CEO Jes Staley noted that financial conditions are somewhat reminiscent of the run-up to the global financial crash of 2008. https://t.co/DNyrNG0FrH

- John Jabbo (@jfjabbo) January 25, 2018

Barclays boss Jes Staley has defended the Government's handling of the City in Brexit talks, saying that it has taken a "keen interest" in keeping London "competitive".

He told CNBC:

"There are a lot of encouraging signs we've gotten from the Bank of England.

"A long way to go, but no, I don't believe the British government has been blind to the importance of London, and to the importance of a bank like Barclays."

The under-fire boss also clarified his comments earlier this week that the markets feel like they were in 2006 just before the financial crisis.

Mr Staley said:

"I mean, there are lots of reasons to be very optimistic. Global economic growth  across the board, is doing great, at roughly 4%.

"What gave me a little bit of cause for concern the other day is, asset values, such the stock market are at all-time highs. Every major industry around the world last year grew by more than 20%, volatility is at an historic low." 

9:27AM Davos: Artificial intelligence is coming to the rescue of the planet

Artificial intelligence is dominating discussions in Davos this morning and our economics expertAmbrose Evans-Pritchardhas sent in this report on how technology can combat plastic waste destroying marine life. 

Artificial intelligence is coming to the rescue of the planet. The new generation of robots could intercept the enormous flood of plastic flowing down the Nile, Indus, Ganges, Yellow, Pearl, Yangtze, Mekong and other rivers before they reach the oceans and destroy marine life.

"I am an optimist. Robots could go to ten rivers and deal with 90pc of our plastic flow almost right away," said Peter Thompson, the UN Special Envoy for the Ocean.

A special session on "Rogue Technology" at the World Economic Forum in Davos turned out to be exactly the opposite. Astonishing break-throughs in AI, drones, a bio-engineering offer the answer to almost all our most dangerous threats.

It is even becoming possible to fiddle with methane genes to cut cattle flatulence and slow the release of greenhouse gases.

9:20AM Davos: Pound is in a sweet spot at current level, says Chancellor Philip Hammond

Philip Hammond just said he's "interested in Bitcoin" and that it could at some point become "systemically important" in the world economy. Says the Bank of England is looking into it. $BTC#Davos2018

- Mutaz Elnour (@MutazElnour) January 25, 2018

 In light of those controversial Steven Mnuchin comments on the weak dollar, Chancellor Philip Hammond was asked this morning on his thoughts on the current level of the pound.

He told Bloomberg that he is "very happy" with the pound's current level, agreeing that it was currently in a sweet spot where imports are not costly but the UK's exports are still competitive on the market.

Chancellor Philip Hammond also told Davos that Bitcoin could become "systemically important" but urged caution on adopting cryptocurrencies.

We're "very happy" with the strength of the pound at present, Philip Hammond says after it passes $1.43 https://t.co/0vYk6skfq1#WEF18pic.twitter.com/ywsJnTBVpH

- Bloomberg Brexit (@Brexit) January 25, 2018 9:06AM Davos: Hammond attacks tech giants for control over personal data

Arrived in @Davos for the #WEF18 . I'm here to meet business and political leaders to discuss the global economy and building a Britain fit for the future. pic.twitter.com/gHQQJxExB6

- Philip Hammond (@PhilipHammondUK) January 25, 2018

We're getting the first reports from our team who have been up from the crack of dawn to bring you the latest from Davos.

Philip Hammond used his speech on artificial  intelligence to attack Silicon Valley giants taking personal information through those dreaded 24-page-long terms and conditions featured on every purchase you make.

Here'sTim Wallace's report:

Chancellor Philip Hammond has singled out the use of lengthy and often impenetrable terms and conditions attached to digital services which consumers cannot understand and which give the Silicon Valley titans control over individuals' data.

"We have to look at the transaction that citizens make with digital companies when they agree by clicking a button, often without thinking about it, how they agree to give away their data and their rights to the data, and how we regulate that transaction," Mr Hammond said, "AI can be a force for bad as well as a force for good - we have to think carefully about how it will be used by terrorists, by criminals, and those to seek to undermine our society.

"Because this technology is trans-border, we have to think about how we can do this on a global scale."

Privacy and data protection also apply to the use of data by the government - the NHS has a vast database which can be used in life sciences research, but Mr Hammond said it must be done with patients' consent, and in a way which protects their data.

8:55AM Davos: Inside the town housing the global elite for a week

Davos isn't all conference halls and spotlighted panels discussions. Our economics whizzTim Wallaceis sending over his latest snaps of the town housing the great and good from the global elite this week.

Here's what he had to say on this brave soul:

National stereotypes are alive and well - here is a piper outside Aberdeen Standard's site on Davos's Promenade. The best tweeted photo of him wins a bottle of whiskey. He must have cold knees wearing that kilt. 

I see those sunloungers don't have many takers this morning.

Bleary-eyed after a relentless week of networking and drinks parties, this is the statue which greets the world's press as they walk from the media centre to the main conference hall. 

8:46AM Davos: US Treasury Secretary not concerned about short-term level of the dollar

US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin says US fully supportive of UK over the "Brexit issue". "We want to see a successful transition." #WEF18

- Kamal Ahmed (@bbckamal) January 25, 2018

The Trump administration is not concerned about the level of the dollar in the short term, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said this morning a day after sending the greenback to a fresh three-year low.

The dollar tumbled yesterday after Mr Mnuchin endorsed the weaker dollar, arguing that it was good for trade and had helped economic growth.

According to Reuters, he said this morning:

"I thought it was actually balanced and consistent with what I've said before, which is, we are not concerned with where the dollar is in the short term. And it's a very very liquid market."

8:36AM Davos: Artificial intelligence could double economic growth, says Hammond

 Tim Wallace is one of our men on the ground up bright and early in Davos this morning to bring us coverage of Philip Hammond's speech on artificial intelligence.

Mr Hammond predicted that AI "could double the rate of economic growth by 2035 in the advanced economies".

But he also said it will bring big challenges across society, particularly to the future of work:

"We must embrace this technology, we must run towards this change, not try to hide from it and its consequences. But if we are going to do that effectively, we have to acknowledge the societal challenges, we have to manage the societal impacts. We have to take our people with us.

"Let's not create a generation of 21st century Luddites who feel that their only chance for survival is to resist this change."

8:23AM Agenda: Pound extends rally as global elite put Brexit and Theresa May under the spotlight

Welcome to day three of our live blog coverage of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

After an explosive second day at Davos as world leaders railed against Donald Trump's delegation stoking fears of a global trade war, US Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin could pour more fuel on the fire this morning in a press conference scheduled by Trump's team.

The UK and Brexit negotiations take centre stage on day three in the Alps with Chancellor Philip Hammond speaking on artificial intelligence this morning before meeting with British business leaders and Prime Minister Theresa May delivering today's most anticipated speech this afternoon.

Good morning from #Davos . On day3 of #WEF18 UK's PM Theresa May in the spotlight. No dedicated Brexit speech, she will take Big Tech to task. Besides that, Dollar stance of US Admin will in focus in panel w/Mnuchin, Blackrock's Fink and Deutsche's Achleitner. pic.twitter.com/vzYmUG4rdQ

- Holger Zschaepitz (@Schuldensuehner) January 25, 2018

Away from Davos, there is a slew of London-listed companies updating the market, including Sky and ASOS, while the European Central Bank's latest monetary policy meeting dominates proceedings on the Continent.

ECB President Mario Draghi and the Governing Council have hinted that they may announce a shift in their guidance on monetary policy, indicating that the central bank could quicken the tapering of its quantitative easing programme.

urn:contentItem:5Y16-37Y1-DXP9-902M-00000-00Davos 2020: What to watch for at this year’s World Economic Forum2020-01-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisDavos 2020: What to watch for at this year’s World Economic ForumAndrew Edgecliffe-Johnson in New York

World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s a... World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. The event, which begins on Tuesday, has earned a reputation for high-altitude...

World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s a... World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting. The event, which begins on Tuesday, has earned a reputation for high-altitude...

World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s a...

World leaders, chief executives, thinkers and celebrities are gathering in the Swiss mountain town of Davos for the World Economic Forum’s annual meeting.

The event, which begins on Tuesday, has earned a reputation for high-altitude pontificating as the global elite gather to pitch their takes on topics picked by WEF founder Klaus Schwab, from deglobalisation to the fourth industrial revolution. 

This year, as the WEF marks its 50th anniversary, a new urgency hangs over the Alpine town. The prospects for trade and global economic growth, tech companies (feted at previous meetings but now in regulators’ sights), the future of multilateralism and the geopolitical order all face growing challenges.

Adding to attendees’ sense of pressure and self-doubt is a multi-faceted environmental crisis which this year occupies all five of the top slots in the WEF’s annual report on the greatest risks facing the world — for the first time. 

Here are five key subjects that are likely to occupy delegates’ attention at Davos 2020.

Will Donald Trump play nice?

A partial government shutdown kept Donald Trump at home last year, but in 2018 the US president used his Davos speech to strike a combative note on trade— an early sign of the tensions that were to come.

Given that he signed the first phase of his renegotiated deal with China last week, Mr Trump is expected to take a softer tone at this year’s event. Last week he said: “We want those business leaders [in Davos] all to come to the United States.”

But Mr Trump will be closely watched for any geopolitical manoeuvres — his recent decision authorising the killing of Iranian military commander Qassem Soleimani in Iraq has heightened instability across the Middle East.

Davos will be the first time that world leaders, including Germany’s Angela Merkel and Spain’s Pedro Sánchez, have a chance to meet face-to-face to discuss the developments. But some are staying away: France’s Emmanuel Macron and Canada’s Justin Trudeau will not attend, while the UK is sending chancellor Sajid Javid, as Prime Minister Boris Johnson stays at home.

Mr Trump’s appearance on the world stage will be a notable contrast with what is going on back home in Washington — opening arguments in his impeachment trial are expected to begin in the Senate on Tuesday, shortly after his Davos speech.

Can global growth recover?

Although Mr Trump has eased off on the trade rhetoric, the tensions his administration triggered leave lingering questions about the prospects for global growth.

The IMF cited “trade barriers” as a key reason for cutting its economic expansion forecasts last autumn, and on Monday lowered its outlook further.

Earlier this month the World Bank downgraded its global growth forecast for 2020 by 0.2 percentage points to 2.5 per cent, warning that the easing of trade tensions between the US and China is unlikely to deliver a rapid economic improvement.

That leaves Davos attendees to grapple with the question of whether fresh stimulus efforts are needed — and, if so, who should be responsible: governments, or central banks?

Will companies match pledges with substance?

The theme for this year’s meeting — “stakeholders for a cohesive and sustainable world” — reflects the number of chief executives who have pledged to start paying as much attention to employees, customers and the environment as to their shareholders. 

“The centrepiece is stakeholder governance,” said Marty Lipton, the veteran Wall Street lawyer.

Last year’s Business Roundtable letter, signed by 181 US chief executives, became a symbol of the shift away from shareholder primacy. Mr Lipton called for such rhetoric to be matched by action, especially from large investors, following a lead set by BlackRock’s sweeping changes last week. 

The Big Four accounting firms will launch an initiative to standardise how companies report their contributions to the UN’s sustainable development goals.

But for climate campaigner Greta Thunberg — who will be attending — the Davos-going classes are in her crosshairs. Ms Thunberg will demand that business and political leaders halt investments in fossil fuel exploration and extraction, end fossil fuel subsidies and divest from fossil fuels.

At a rally on Friday, she warned those in power: “You haven’t seen anything yet.” 

Can Big Tech be a force for good?

From digital privacy to taxes, there is much at stake for the tech executives who are descending on Davos, Mr Schwab told the FT last week.

Satya Nadella, who pledged last week that Microsoft would be “carbon negative” within a decade, Google’s Sundar Pichai and Huawei’s Ren Zhengfei will all address the forum.

Facebook chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg will host journalists and publishers in a “Facebook Space” set up to persuade them that the company, which is under pressure from Brussels to Washington, can increase economic opportunity and “bring the world closer together”. 

Its challenge was illustrated by a recent report from media monitoring group Media Tenor, which found that the technology sector is now seen by the press “with the same scepticism as the tobacco or finance industry”.

Do shoe grips offset carbon footprints?

After years of mocking headlines about the fuel-hungry private jets that ship in delegates to wring their hands over climate change, the WEF has this year encouraged participants to use low-carbon transport options such as the train.

It is also offering shoe grips to encourage them to walk the snowy promenade between meetings rather than take cars. 

The effort to be sustainable extends to advising caterers not to serve luxuries such as foie gras and caviar, and one day of the meeting has been set aside for “vegetarian menus and the discovery of alternative protein sources”. 

This year’s events — including the launch of an initiative to plant 1tn trees in the next decade — will take place in rooms decorated with seaweed-based paint and carpets made from “end-of life fishing nets”. The scores of companies hosting their own events have been asked to consider offering local wines and “mountain herbal infusions” instead of imported drinks.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5Y2W-97V1-F021-63FG-00000-00Davos doesn't get it - tech isn't the silver bullet of the climate crisis;Governments need to pass legislation now that incentivises zero-carbon economies, instead of relying on technologies that may never come2020-01-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisVOICESVersion:2Davos doesn't get it - tech isn't the silver bullet of the climate crisisGovernments need to pass legislation now that incentivises zero-carbon economies, instead of relying on technologies that may never comeTrisha De Borchgrave

This year's Annual Meeting of the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos opened last week with a mood of restrained optimism. The global economy, after all, is tootling along: there are generally low levels of unemployment, interest rates and inflation; progress has been made in the China/US trade war; and, closer to home, a "Brexit resolution" of sorts.

But fear for the future of the planet quickly cast a shadow on this sunny outlook. All other risks to global stability - wealth inequality, mass migration, conflict - were overwhelmed by concerns that governments and companies are insufficiently committed to combating the climate crisis.

WEF Presenters displayed powerful visuals showing how rising sea levels will disappear large chunks of Shanghai and Florida; former Vice-President Al Gore warned the conference that if we continue at our current rates of consumption, by 2050, there will be more plastic in the ocean than fish. Meanwhile, Greta Thunberg sat impassively on stage with the luminosity of a mystic. Shy yet with a single-minded intensity, the 17-year-old delivered her message that the world must act now to prevent temperatures from swelling above 1.5 degrees.

The WEF's 2020 manifesto was "stakeholder capitalism", a model in which corporations have a duty beyond their shareholders to society at large. But, as growing pressure from the financial sector reveals, CEO's are struggling to make meaningful strides towards their environmental, social and governance (ESG) goals. Some business leaders accepted the need for concrete government action, such as subsidising renewables, taxing carbon and regulating big tech. Others joined civil society leaders to push into new frontiers of sustainability, such as "re-scaling people" and "mind-facturing" smarter cities.

It was significant that geopolitics hardly featured in Davos this year, even in the context of re-configuring an outdated global order. Instead, maintaining peace was about raising awareness that the planet's future survival depends more today on its disappearing Amazonian rain forests than on nuclear proliferation in the Middle East.

This change in emphasis was difficult for some to absorb, including a group of confused SwissDavos old-timers who, coated in luxurious furs, were overheard questioning why the climate was featuring so heavily at this year's forum.

Heads of state who typically attend Davos in the hopes of securing foreign investment this year pitched their sustainability credentials alongside their credit-worthiness.

Among them were Pedro Sanchez (Spain's on-off prime minister), with his determination to "deliver an ecological transition"; Angela Merkel, boasting of her country's coal detox and the new EU Commission President Ursula von de Leyden, touting Europe's Green New Deal.

Meanwhile, The Obama-esque Juan Guaidó, Venezuela's leader-in-waiting, delivered a deeply moving speech, pledging to bring dignity and prosperity back to his people, emphasising the importance of safeguarding Venezuela and Colombia's common natural resources - and elicited one of the conference's few standing ovations.

Davos 2020 was less a new dawn to a greener planet than a dawning to the business community that its time may be up; that their carbon-intensive, profit-dominated ways of doing business are impoverishing life on this planet.

That said, many hoped that climate consciousness could be good for business. A couple of tech industry attendees passing each other in the corridor, exchanged briefings. "How's the future?" called out one. "We won!" replied the other. The Chief Strategy Officer of GSMA estimated that 5G connectivity could add $2.2 trillion to the world economy.

A digitised, 5G-connected and less extractive world should also be more environmentally-friendly and sustainable. And for some, including WEF founder Klaus Schwab, greater connectivity could deliver greater governance efficiency and nanosecond accountability, making the sort of breaches of political trust that have driven the recent populist upsurge more difficult in the future.

Yet Greta had a warning for those who are counting on the powers of technology to solve the world's climate crisis. Governments need to pass legislation now that incentivises zero-carbon economies, instead of relying on technologies that may never come.

In any case, perhaps next year's Davos meeting will focus on the new security risks of the 25 billion devices connected to the new internet of things.
