Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5V0W-J0C1-JBCN-43RX-00000-00D.C. attorney general sues Facebook over Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal2018-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisD.C. attorney general sues Facebook over Cambridge Analytica privacy scandalTONY ROMM

WASHINGTON - Nine months after a whistleblower revealed that Facebook had allowed outsiders to improperly access personal information about millions of its users, the social media giant faced its first major rebuke from regulators in the United States - a lawsuit filed by the attorney general of the District of Columbia.

The lawsuit from Karl Racine on Wednesday targeted Facebook mainly for its entanglement with Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy that harvested names, "likes" and other data from the social site without users' permission. The incident, which affected more than 87 million users, beginning in 2014, came to light this March, sparking investigations around the world.

The opening salvo from the D.C. attorney general ended a protracted silence on the part of many U.S. regulators, who have faced immense pressure - from members of Congress and average web users - to discipline Facebook for what many see as a reckless disregard for online privacy. Some of Silicon Valley's toughest critics have urged the government to slap Facebook with severe fines and other penalties that might force it to rethink a business model that monetizes the most intimate details of consumers' lives.

"It's about time," said Christopher Wylie, who exposed the Cambridge Analytica controversy through reports in several news organizations.

But the fact that the first legal action came from local D.C. officials - not their federal counterparts located a 10-minutes walk away - left some privacy advocates fearful that the U.S. government's primary consumer-protection cop increasingly is outmatched by Silicon Valley. That agency, the Federal Trade Commission, started investigating the Cambridge Analytica controversy weeks after it became public, out of concern that Facebook violated a pledge it made to regulators to honor its users' privacy settings. On Wednesday, representatives of the FTC again declined to comment on its progress.

"The agency needs to show us that it can stand up to Big Tech," said Hal Singer, a senior fellow at George Washington University's Institute of Public Policy.

Facebook said in a statement Wednesday it is "reviewing the complaint and (looks) forward to continuing our discussions with attorneys general in D.C. and elsewhere." Facebook's stock price closed down more than 7 percent Wednesday.

The D.C. case threatens to develop into an even worse headache for Facebook. Racine told reporters that his office has "had discussions with a number of other states that are similarly interested in protecting the data and personal information of their consumers," though he cautioned there is no formal agreement for them to proceed jointly. And the attorney general's aides said they could add additional charges to their lawsuit as other details about Facebook's privacy lapses become public.

In the months since the Cambridge Analytica scandal began, Facebook has fielded considerable criticism for a series of privacy missteps. Last week, Facebook said as many as 6.8 million users' photos may have been improperly accessed by third-party apps. On Tuesday, new details emerged about Facebook's extensive data-sharing arrangements with corporate partners, including Amazon and Spotify. The report from The New York Times quickly triggered another round of calls from Capitol Hill for the tech giant to be penalized.

"It appears that Facebook has not been honest with Congress or the public about how it treats its users' data," said Rep. Frank Pallone, D-N.J., the incoming chairman of the tech-focused House Energy and Commerce Committee. "Based on these revelations, I'm concerned that Facebook may have provided the Committee with inaccurate, incomplete or misleading responses to our questions, and we'll be following-up."

Facebook's troubles with Cambridge Analytica came to light in March, after Wylie revealed that the political firm sought to create "psychographic" profiles about social media users - by analyzing their Facebook data - and target them with messages that preyed on their hopes and fears. Among those affected were half of D.C. residents, said Racine, the District's attorney general, when he announced his lawsuit in a call with reporters. Citing the region's consumer-protection law, Racine contended that Facebook misled users about the security of their data, made it difficult for users to control their privacy settings and failed to inform them promptly after discovering Cambridge Analytica improperly accessed personal information.

"Facebook's lax oversight of its privacy protocols and confusing privacy settings put the personal information of millions of Americans at risk," Racine said.

The D.C. lawsuit also took issue with other business practices at Facebook, including its relationships with device-makers, such as BlackBerry, that could access social data in ways that could "override" a user's privacy settings, according to the complaint. In response, the attorney general's office said the District sought an injunction to "ensure Facebook puts in place protocols and safeguards to monitor users' data," along with "restitution for consumers, penalties, and costs."

While D.C. takes aim at Facebook, federal regulators remained quiet about their next steps. The Cambridge Analytica controversy initially drew the attention of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department. The FTC in particular has probed whether Facebook's relationship with Cambridge Analytica - and its handling of users' data - violated a 2011 agreement brokered by the U.S. government that required the tech giant to improve its privacy practices or risk major fines. The penalty, which is assessed based on the total number of violations and users affected, could reach into the billions of dollars, experts have said.

In recent weeks, though, FTC Chairman Joe Simons repeatedly has declined to update members of Congress about the probe - or the extent to which the government has started studying Facebook's other privacy mishaps. Appearing at a Senate hearing in November, Simons said it would be "inappropriate for me to comment on a specific nonpublic investigation" - even though the FTC itself previously confirmed that it is investigating.

The FTC's silence did little to satisfy Sen. Richard Blumenthal, D-Conn. "We need to know when you will have some results, because these continuing violations clearly show we have something more than a single bad-actor problem, and it is not only Facebook," he said at the time. "I think you have an obligation to tell us when you think this investigation will be done."

Veterans of the FTC - which tends to operate in secrecy - acknowledged that the agency can take upwards of a year to probe a violation fully, and that the scope of investigations can expand as new information emerges. But analysts said the commission faces a major time-sensitive test with Facebook: Should the FTC fail to act swiftly in the social media giant's case, at a moment when its privacy mishaps are piling up, the agency could find itself weakened in its ability to hold the rest of Silicon Valley accountable.

"The stakes are extremely high for the agency," said Marshall Steinbaum, research director at the New York-based Roosevelt Institute, a left-leaning think tank. "The companies want Congress to empower the FTC as the sole arbiter of privacy issues. If the companies can run the table on them … then we can't seriously entertain the idea that this agency is capable of regulating the sector."

"Based on these revelations, I'm concerned that Facebook may have provided the Committee with inaccurate, incomplete, or misleading responses to our questions, and we'll be following up."

Facebook's troubles with Cambridge Analytica came to light in March when Wylie revealed that the political firm sought to create "psychographic" profiles about social media users, using their Facebook data, and target them with messages that preyed on their hopes and fears. Among those affected were half of all D.C. residents, Racine said when he announced his lawsuit in a call with reporters.

Citing the District's consumer protection law, Racine contended that Facebook misled users about the security of their data, made it difficult for users to control their privacy settings and failed to inform them promptly after discovering Cambridge Analytica had improperly accessed personal information.

"Facebook's lax oversight of its privacy protocols and confusing privacy settings put the personal information of millions of Americans at risk," Racine said.

The D.C. lawsuit also took issue with other business practices at Facebook, including its relationships with device-makers such as BlackBerry that could access social data in ways that could "override" a user's privacy settings, according to the complaint. The attorney general's office sought an injunction to "ensure Facebook puts in place protocols and safeguards to monitor users' data" and provide "restitution for consumers, penalties, and costs."

While the District took aim at Facebook, federal regulators remained quiet about their next steps. The Cambridge Analytica controversy initially drew the attention of multiple agencies - the Securities and Exchange Commission, the FTC and the Justice Department. The FTC in particular has probed whether Facebook's relationship with Cambridge Analytica - and its handling of users' data - violated a 2011 agreement brokered by the U.S. government that required the tech giant to improve its privacy practices or risk major fines. The penalty, which is assessed based on the total number of violations and users affected, could reach into the billions of dollars, experts have said.

In recent weeks, though, FTC Chairman Joseph Simons has repeatedly declined to update members of Congress about the probe or the extent to which the government has started studying Facebook's other privacy mishaps.

Appearing at a Senate hearing in November, Simons said it would be "inappropriate for me to comment on a specific nonpublic investigation" - even though the FTC itself previously confirmed it was investigating.

The FTC's silence did little to satisfy Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.). "We need to know when you will have some results because these continuing violations clearly show we have something more than a single bad actor problem, and it is not only Facebook," he said at the time. "I think you have an obligation to tell us when you think this investigation will be done."

Veterans of the FTC, which tends to operate in secrecy, said that the agency can take upward of a year to probe a violation fully, and that the scope of investigations can expand as new information emerges.

But analysts said the commission faces a major, time-sensitive test with Facebook: Should the FTC fail to act swiftly against the social-media giant, at a moment when its privacy mishaps are piling up, the agency could find itself weakened in its ability to hold the rest of Silicon Valley accountable.

"The stakes are extremely high for the agency," said Marshall Steinbaum, research director at the New York-based Roosevelt Institute, a left-leaning think tank. "The companies want Congress to empower the FTC as the sole arbiter of privacy issues. If the companies can run the table on them . . . then we can't seriously entertain the idea that this agency is capable of regulating the sector."

brian.fung@washpost.com

aaron.davis@washpost.com

Craig Timberg contributed to this report.

urn:contentItem:5V0W-4411-JCDY-T4H3-00000-00D.C. attorney general sues Facebook over privacy lapses2018-12-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisA sectionPg. A24D.C. attorney general sues Facebook over privacy lapsesTony Romm;Brian Fung;Aaron C. Davis;Craig Timberg

First regulator to act in Cambridge Analytica case as FTC stays silent

Nine months after a whistleblower revealed Facebook had allowed outsiders to improperly access personal information about millions of its users, the social media giant faced its first major rebuke from regulators in the United States - a lawsuit filed by the attorney general of the District of Columbia.

The lawsuit from Karl A. Racine on Wednesday targeted Facebook mainly for its entanglement with Cambridge Analytica, a political consultancy that harvested names, "likes" and other data from the social site without users' permission. The incident, which affected more than 87 million users beginning in 2014, came to light in March, sparking investigations around the world.

The opening salvo from the D.C. attorney general ended a protracted silence on the part of many U.S. regulators, who have faced immense pressure - from members of Congress and average web users - to discipline Facebook for what many see as a reckless disregard for online privacy. Some of Silicon Valley's toughest critics have urged the government to slap Facebook with severe fines and other penalties that might force it to rethink a business model that monetizes the most intimate details of consumers' lives.

"It's about time," said Christopher Wylie, who exposed the Cambridge Analytica controversy through reports in several news organizations.

But the fact that the first legal action came from District officials - not their federal counterparts located a 10-minute walk away - left some privacy advocates fearful that the U.S. government's primary consumer-protection cop increasingly is outmatched by Silicon Valley.

That agency, the Federal Trade Commission, started investigating the Cambridge Analytica controversy weeks after it became public out of concern that Facebook violated a pledge it made to regulators to honor its users' privacy settings. On Wednesday, spokespeople at the FTC again declined to comment on their progress.

"The agency needs to show us that it can stand up to Big Tech," said Hal Singer, a senior fellow at George Washington University's Institute of Public Policy.

Asked about the lawsuit, Facebook said in a statement Wednesday it was "reviewing the complaint and [looks] forward to continuing our discussions with attorneys general in D.C. and elsewhere."

Facebook's stock price closed down more than 7 percent Wednesday.

The D.C. case threatens to develop into an even worse headache for Facebook. Racine told reporters that his office has "had discussions with a number of other states that are similarly interested in protecting the data and personal information of their consumers," although he cautioned there is no formal agreement for them to proceed jointly. And the attorney general's aides said they could add additional charges to their lawsuit as other details about Facebook's privacy lapses become public.

In the months since the Cambridge Analytica scandal began, Facebook has fielded considerable criticism for a series of privacy missteps.

Last week, Facebook admitted that as many as 6.8 million users' photos may have been improperly accessed by third-party apps. And on Tuesday, new details emerged about Facebook's extensive data-sharing arrangements with corporate partners, including Amazon and Spotify. The report from the New York Times quickly triggered another round of calls on Capitol Hill for the tech giant to be penalized.

"It appears that Facebook has not been honest with Congress or the public about how it treats its users' data," said Rep. Frank Pallone Jr. (D-N.J.), the incoming chairman of the tech-focused House Energy and Commerce Committee. "Based on these revelations, I'm concerned that Facebook may have provided the Committee with inaccurate, incomplete, or misleading responses to our questions, and we'll be following up."

Facebook's troubles with Cambridge Analytica came to light in March when Wylie revealed that the political firm sought to create "psychographic" profiles about social media users, using their Facebook data, and target them with messages that preyed on their hopes and fears. Among those affected were half of all D.C. residents, Racine said when he announced his lawsuit in a call with reporters.

Citing the District's consumer protection law, Racine contended that Facebook misled users about the security of their data, made it difficult for users to control their privacy settings and failed to inform them promptly after discovering Cambridge Analytica had improperly accessed personal information.

"Facebook's lax oversight of its privacy protocols and confusing privacy settings put the personal information of millions of Americans at risk," Racine said.

The D.C. lawsuit also took issue with other business practices at Facebook, including its relationships with device-makers such as BlackBerry that could access social data in ways that could "override" a user's privacy settings, according to the complaint. The attorney general's office sought an injunction to "ensure Facebook puts in place protocols and safeguards to monitor users' data" and provide "restitution for consumers, penalties, and costs."

While the District took aim at Facebook, federal regulators remained quiet about their next steps. The Cambridge Analytica controversy initially drew the attention of multiple agencies - the Securities and Exchange Commission, the FTC and the Justice Department. The FTC in particular has probed whether Facebook's relationship with Cambridge Analytica - and its handling of users' data - violated a 2011 agreement brokered by the U.S. government that required the tech giant to improve its privacy practices or risk major fines. The penalty, which is assessed based on the total number of violations and users affected, could reach into the billions of dollars, experts have said.

In recent weeks, though, FTC Chairman Joseph Simons has repeatedly declined to update members of Congress about the probe or the extent to which the government has started studying Facebook's other privacy mishaps.

Appearing at a Senate hearing in November, Simons said it would be "inappropriate for me to comment on a specific nonpublic investigation" - even though the FTC itself previously confirmed it was investigating.

The FTC's silence did little to satisfy Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.). "We need to know when you will have some results because these continuing violations clearly show we have something more than a single bad actor problem, and it is not only Facebook," he said at the time. "I think you have an obligation to tell us when you think this investigation will be done."

Veterans of the FTC, which tends to operate in secrecy, said that the agency can take upward of a year to probe a violation fully, and that the scope of investigations can expand as new information emerges.

But analysts said the commission faces a major, time-sensitive test with Facebook: Should the FTC fail to act swiftly against the social-media giant, at a moment when its privacy mishaps are piling up, the agency could find itself weakened in its ability to hold the rest of Silicon Valley accountable.

"The stakes are extremely high for the agency," said Marshall Steinbaum, research director at the New York-based Roosevelt Institute, a left-leaning think tank. "The companies want Congress to empower the FTC as the sole arbiter of privacy issues. If the companies can run the table on them . . . then we can't seriously entertain the idea that this agency is capable of regulating the sector."

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60MY-GRD1-F19Y-C0YM-00000-00Deadline set for Borsa Italiana bids; Turkey cuts banks' borrowing limits2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisExtraDeadline set for Borsa Italiana bids; Turkey cuts banks' borrowing limitsAdrian Jimenea

S&P Global Market Intelligence's daily overview of essential Financials news in Europe.

TOP NEWS

* Italian bank Intesa Sanpaolo SpA is likely joining local peer Cassa depositi e prestiti SpA and Netherlands-based exchange operator Euronext NV in a potential bid for Borsa Italiana SpA, insiders told Bloomberg News. London Stock Exchange Group PLC, Borsa Italiana's owner, will accept indicative bids for the unit until mid-September, sources told Reuters. Meanwhile, CDP and Euronext are teaming up to present an expression of interest to LSE Group for fixed-income trading platform MTS SpA by Aug. 21, MF reported.

* Effective today, the Turkish central bank halved the current borrowing limits of banks for overnight transactions as the regulator seeks to support the weakening domestic lira currency.

As 'big tech' dominates cloud use for banks, regulators may need to get tougher Banks rely heavily on a small number of "big tech" players for cloud infrastructure. Industry insiders say a concentration of power in the hands of just a few providers creates risks for the financial sector.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan top gainers in strong Q2 i-bank trading The leading global investment banks had another strong trading quarter, with fixed income, currencies and commodities driving most of the revenue gains, S&P Global Market Intelligence data shows. U.S. banks continued to outperform European peers.

BANKING

* Atom Bank PLC plans to raise as much as £150 million in a share sale in the autumn, which would become the British digital lender's largest equity fundraising to date as it seeks to ramp up its expansion, sources told Sky News.

* Intesa Sanpaolo increased its stake in Italian payments company Nexi SpA to 10.489% from 9.917% following Intesa's successful takeover of Unione di Banche Italiane SpA, which owned 0.572% of Nexi, according to Il Sole 24 Ore.

* Dutch bank Van Lanschot Kempen NV will acquire all shares in domestic peer Hof Hoorneman Bankiers NV for an undisclosed sum. The deal is expected to close by year-end.

* The public prosecution in Cologne, Germany, yesterday raided offices of Hauck & Aufhäuser Privatbankiers AG and Varengold Bank AG on suspicion of alleged involvements in illicit cum-ex dividend deals and related tax evasion, Süddeutsche Zeitung and Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung reported.

* Urs Isenrich will leave as Switzerland-based Bank Linth LLB AG's head of finance, loans and risk management at the end of September, finews.com reported.

* Liechtenstein-based VP Bank AG postponed to 2026 the timeline of its new strategy cycle, under which it aims to yield a net income of CHF100 million, in light of the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.

* Portuguese prosecutors are to study a series of asset sales by state-rescued Novo Banco SA, which has faced intense scrutiny in recent weeks for selling off real estate holdings at low prices while continuing to receive loans from the country's bank resolution fund, Jornal de Negócios reported.

* José Azevedo Pereira is set to replace Fernando Teixeira dos Santos as executive chairman of EuroBic SA, formerly Banco BIC Português SA, while Pedro Maia will succeed Diogo Barrote as chairman of the small lender, according to ECO.

* Danish fintech company Lunar A/S, which received a banking license in 2019, is launching a new bank for small businesses, Finans reported.

* The IMF is monitoring the potential impact of an indictment against Moldova's Banca Comercial Victoriabank SA on a new IMF-backed program focusing on strengthening rule of law in the country, SEENews said. A Moldovan court recently authorized prosecutors to seize 1.9 billion lei worth of assets at Victoriabank, with the decision raising concern at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is one of the lender's shareholders.

FINANCIAL SERVICES

* City of London Group PLC is in advanced discussions with a third party for fundraising, which if approved by shareholders and regulators, could allow the company to clinch in the fourth quarter an authorization with restriction to operate as a bank and a full banking license in the first half of 2020.

* The German finance ministry said former Wirecard AG CEO Markus Braun met with central bank executive board member Burkhard Balz in September 2019 amid allegations of accounting lapses in the now-insolvent payments group as Braun sought to boost contact with authorities, Bloomberg News reported.

* British home credit lender Morses Club PLC's digital division, Shelby Finance Ltd., tapped Modulr Finance Ltd. as supplier for its U Account business, replacing Wirecard unit Wirecard Card Solutions Ltd.

* Amigo Holdings PLC's shares rose at least 6.3% yesterday after founder James Benamor said he plans to return to the embattled British guarantor loans provider, The Times reported. In a tweet, Benamor, who stepped down in March, said he would propose to the company's board to return, after which a shareholder vote could be called.

* U.K.-based Sabre Insurance Group PLC named Andy Pomfret chairman, effective Sept. 1, replacing Patrick Snowball.

* Bermuda-based Randall & Quilter Investment Holdings Ltd. will acquire the entire issued share capital U.K.-based Inceptum Insurance Co. Ltd. for an undisclosed amount.

* France's CNP Assurances SA will create a new joint venture with Brazil-based Caixa Econômica Federal specializing in consórcio collective savings products, Les Echos reported.

* Belgium-based Allianz Benelux SA will transfer a closed book of classical life retail insurance policies and 4,500 mortgage loans to Monument Assurance Belgium NV, including a portfolio of 95,000 policies with technical provisions of 1.4 billion under Solvency II.

POLICY AND REGULATION

* The Serbian central bank introduced new measures facilitating access of retail bank clients to housing loans in order to support the country's construction industry amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The measures will be in place until the end of 2021.

INDUSTRY NEWS

* Denmark announced a new targeted corporate tax on banks and pension funds and higher taxes on the stock market returns of the wealthiest investors, Bloomberg News reported. The financial sector is estimated to pay an additional tax of 1.5 billion kroner from 2023 if the proposal is approved.

MARKETS

Click here for a summary of indexes on the MI platform.

Quiz: Test your knowledge of the Market Intelligence platform to win an Amazon.com voucher

Erin Tanchico, Arno Maierbrugger, Danielle Rossingh, Esben Svendsen, Beata Fojcik, Heather O'Brian, Brian McCulloch, Sophie Davies and Helen Popper contributed to this report.

The Daily Dose is updated as of 7 a.m. London time. Some external links may require a subscription. Links are current as of publication time, and we are not responsible if those links are unavailable later.

urn:contentItem:5SXK-R461-JBHT-D22C-00000-00Deadly Northern California Wildfire Taking Down Everything In Its Path; ExxonMobil Shares Fall 2.2 Percent Premarket After Earnings Fall Short Of Estimates; 2Q GDP (1st Read): 4.1% (Act) Vs. 4.1% (Est); President Trump to Speak on Economy at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time From the White House2018-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisDeadly Northern California Wildfire Taking Down Everything In Its Path; ExxonMobil Shares Fall 2.2 Percent Premarket After Earnings Fall Short Of Estimates; 2Q GDP (1st Read): 4.1% (Act) Vs. 4.1% (Est); President Trump to Speak on Economy at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time From the White HouseLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday, and coming to you live this morning from nation's capital, where I will sit down for an exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence. You will see that on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on Fox News Channel this Sunday and here on "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" on Monday morning.

Happy Friday. It is Friday, July 27th. And your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. one the East Coast. The economy firing on all cylinders. The first look at the second quarter GDP, it's out in less than 30 minutes. It is expected to show growth in the economy of 4.1 percent. President Trump sounding of speaking in Iowa yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The predictions from 3.8 to 5.3, right? I have been saying we're going to do all pretty well but nobody thought we were going to be this big. When I took over, those numbers were bad and they were heading in the wrong direction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Ahead of the report, futures are mixed. Take a look, Dow Industrials up 10 points, S&P 500 lower by half a point and the NASDAQ is up 3-3/4 points. Fractional moves across the board. Mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street. The Dow was up but others down, the Dow posting a triple digit gain while the NASDAQ and S&P 500 were in the red. In Europe this morning, gains across the board.

Take a look, money moving into equities in a big way, DAX Index up a half of a percent as is the FT-100 in London. In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher with the exception of China, Shanghai Composite down a third of a percent. Investors are also watching earnings, Twitter earnings out last hour, decline in monthly users, taking the stock down this morning. It is down 16 percent on Twitter as investors are rethinking what the growth numbers are.

Really, for social media companies. We are waiting on ExxonMobil this morning. The first of the oil giants to report their second quarter this morning. We'll get the highlights from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange coming up with Exxon shares down almost one percent going into the numbers. Then there's this, finally coming home. North Korea handing over the remains of some U.S. soldiers killed in the line of duty during the Korean War.

We have the details as one of President Trump's promises becomes reality. The wildfire in Northern California turns deadly. The flames tearing through small towns, forcing thousands to flee their homes. The very latest developments coming up this morning straight ahead. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down in New York, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell.

The Wall Street Journals' assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman, and national security analyst Morgan Ortagus. A lot happening this morning, guys. Good morning to you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria Bartiromo. I can't wait for that number of (INAUDIBLE) find out how fast this economy is growing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it was Atlanta Fed, James Freeman, who predicted 4.8 percent. But did they walk that down to 4.5 percent recently? I know --

FREEMAN: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: They might even be slightly under four after that data we got Thursday, but --

BARTIROMO: Right, right.

FREEMAN: But still very optimistic and, you know, more good news, this rising household formation. That was kind of a story of the Obama years was kids living in parents' basements waiting for the opportunity to move out so that that surge I think is very hopeful sign that we turn the corner and maybe some of those millennials who everyone says, believe in socialism will now see some of the benefits of free markets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Morgan?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think certainly, anyone running us, a Democratic socialist, this number today is not going to help the cause, you know, which is a good thing. We can just look as far as south as Venezuela to see what socialism does in our hemisphere. So, it's going to be a good number today and it's going to help the White House continue to focus on jobs.

And the people that elected Donald Trump, that care about getting their jobs back, they care about economy.

BARTIROMO: And we're going to get the White House reaction firsthand. I'm here in Washington this morning for an exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence that will air this weekend on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES," on Fox News at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will have -- plus more of that interview of my sit down on Monday morning right here on "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" beginning 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Don't miss my interview with the Vice President, coming out. Coming up on the program. We have this breaking news, we want to get out right now. Exxon earnings are out. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the details. And Nick, ExxonMobil shares were down going into the quarter.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. And you know what, it's now the third quarter of weakness for Exxon. A big miss on earnings per share, Maria. You could see it's now down 1.8 percent, 92 cents versus a buck 27. Revenue did come in and beat 73.5 versus 72.5. The CEOs saying second quarter results were primarily impacted by significantly scheduled maintenance undertaken to support operational integrity.

But the big picture here is that it's a miss, again. Last quarter the profit missed on the estimates on refining and chemical woes. So again, another miss for Exxon, Dow component too. So we'll watch for that. But for the most part, we've seen a lot of beats, 72 percent have beaten on revenue and 84 percent have beaten on earnings per share thus far. That being said, let's also take a look at Twitter which this morning you noted, the active users fell by a million.

So that really surprised Wall Street because they were expecting a million gain in users. So, with that move to the downside, the stock has been down about 16 percent. And take a look at Facebook which had the biggest fall ever since its 2012 IPO. It's the biggest loss ever for a company over 100 billion lost in one day. Zuckerberg losses 16 billion of his own money and so you can see the stock is coming back by one percent.

But we have a discussion about this yesterday, some people want to consider buying this back and others don't want to touch it concerned about management and the company overall, Maria. And I will leave with you this, Jeffrey Frankel just came over from Stuart Frankel. You know him well and basically continues to say, there is no better place to buy them in the U.S., and he reiterated equity is the place to go.

The volatility has been wild, what an exciting week it has been and the value players have been picking them and liquidating in them throughout the day. We had a wild close yesterday too on some very heavy volume. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm just scratching my head, how do you have a miss when oil prices are where they are. We're going to take a look at that, Nic. Thank you so much as you see, that stock is lower. The GDP report less than 30 minutes away. That will likely set the tone for markets but because of the ExxonMobil numbers, things have come in a bit for futures. We're expecting a higher opening but not where we were earlier.

President Trump touted the strength of the economy and alluded to the strong GDP number yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We've never seen anything like going on right now. We're going to have very big numbers announced tomorrow. I don't know what they are but a lot of big predictions, I think they're going to be to be terrific. You know, we took over, it was really low and it was heading lower, a lot lower and was going to be there fast and great things have happened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now to talk more about that, Fox News contributor, former senior adviser for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove. Karl, good to see you, my friend.

KARL ROVE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. And look, I want to get started on a positive note. I'm willing to contribute $5.00 to the Zuckerberg relief fund. Make sure the lad gets a nice lunch today. So, five bucks, count me in.

BARTIROMO: Ohm goodness. Listen, he is still a multibillionaire, Karl, so let's not go crazy on this upset for Facebook stock, but what's your take in -- I want to ask you about that because the -- your reaction to what we're seeing in terms of the censoring of conservative ideas on Twitter, on Facebook and this backlash that these companies are now facing.

ROVE: Well, I think that's a part of the story. The bigger part of the story is the vulnerability of our tech companies. These tech companies have grown so fast, the expectations are so high, they've got so many things that they have to deal with, whether it's like concerns on Twitter about Conservatives being sort of dislodged and pushed to the side or Facebook where the question is your privacy rights.

So, all of these, many issues that they face I think demonstrated the vulnerability of this once thought invulnerable big tech companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And we'll see if there's a heavier government hand in terms of regulation as a result of some of this. They're going to be going testifying in front of the Senate, Sheryl Sandberg and others, so we'll watch that. But let me ask you about the GDP and the economy, Karl because when President comments on economic data, before it's actually released, it's usually an indicator of the strong report. What are you expecting?

ROVE: Well, he doesn't know what the number is. When he talked yesterday in Granite City, I want to be clear, he had not yet been informed, he was probably informed maybe sometime this morning, maybe sometime late last night. But Presidents are not supposed to talk about that number publicly once they're given it. So my suspicion is he was looking at the same day that we've all been looking at.

April, May and June, capital investment, investment in capital goods excluding aircraft up dramatically, April, May, June, retail numbers up significantly. So this is going to be the first GDP number that's going to be actually have all of the regulatory reform baked in and see the beginning of the impact of the tax reform measure. So, we've seen estimates from three to five, the consensus appears to be just around four, just slightly north of four.

And it's going to be a very good number. Ironically, I will tell you politically this is a -- you can't just bask in the glory of the moment. I've been through a couple of these moments in the White House myself and there's an ironic thing, is when the economy is really going good, they pay momentary attention to good news like this and then they sort of say, well, the economy is doing good. I'm on the other things.

So the administration needs to not only sort of say, well, look at the good results of our policies, but all incidentally, here are some additional things we want to do to keep our economy going strong because there is a -- there is a -- real -- you know, temptation by ordinary people to say, I'm banking that the economy is good, now I'm looking on other things that concern me.

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes. But that's the thing, I mean, we talk about this every morning and that is trade. And we are wondering if these tariffs and trade are going to have an impact on this number, Karl.

ROVE: Well, about in fact, the people over the American Action Network say one thing might be baked into these numbers is people -- companies were afraid of the impact of tariffs so they forward ordered, they said, OK, I'm going to need more steel and aluminum, so before that tariff gets put in on steel and aluminum, I'm going to preorder it. There are things that might be coming from China.

Where I want to get ahead of the tariffs so that I get these -- so there may be some and we'll see that in the inventory numbers but, yes, there are some instability there. The president this week with the E.U., they already change (INAUDIBLE) foe, now we're going to be allies together in reducing tariffs and tariffs barriers, non-tariff barriers and we're going to be also I thought largely passed over in public comment but really important.

The E.U. and the United States are going to be working together at the two in order to rein in China's trade abuses. So good news on that front but you're right, this number, the last quarter, there have been, you know, this was the quarter of talk about tariff wars and trade wars and that's going to be reflected maybe to the good in people pre-ordering but also reflected in the ongoing with people being concerned about what the economy is going to look like in the months ahead.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But, look, Dagen has pointed this out correctly, like the Wall Street Journal editorial board, like 24 lawmakers who are up in arms and have been yesterday that these trade -- these tariffs are cutting into growth. Correct, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: They are. Karl, when you have the President on the -- essentially at a campaign rally as he was yesterday bragging about the steel industry coming back. BARTIROMO: From your standpoint and from a legal perspective, how can the states help to stop election meddling?

RAY: I think, frankly, effort. I mean, there doesn't seem to be much bipartisan dispute about the fact that it is in the country's interest to secure our elections. It's a little difficult, you know, given the fact that it's an operation across the country that is controlled and governed by local authority.

So, it has to be a coordinated effort but, you know, I think, whenever in this country, we put our minds to an objective that everyone seems to believe is in the country's best interest, that is to say that we have secure elections, and that it can't --

You know, we do what we can do, so that foreign interests including Russia, cannot penetrate that system. I don't think it, you know, is an impossible task. I think that's a task that is well worth the effort. I imagined that. You'll see the result of that after --as soon as the midterm elections.

BARTIROMO: So this meeting today, is there anything that this meeting can result in where we actually have more confidence that we can stop this?

RAY: I think it's, you know, an emerging national consensus. But, I think, also, we clearly know based upon the intelligence community, that there was concerted effort and some degree of penetration by Russian interests.

And, you know, that, obviously, needs to be addressed, and will. I think what the - you know, what the President can do is lead the federal effort to coordinate with state and local efforts, to do what is necessary to secure the integrity of election results and also to ensure the integrity of the -- of the election process.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Robert, let me switch gears. First, it takes -- I don't -- I don't think we should be cavalier with this process or with this term, number one.

Number two, I don't think that this raises the level of high crimes and misdemeanors, that's really high standard.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What's your take on this? Does Rosenstein's actions, warrant impeachment? There obviously is a big movement to get him out from the right, with a couple of lawmakers like Mark Meadows, pushing for it.

RAY: Look, ordinarily, the process would be, if Congress is unhappy with compliance by the Department of Justice and specifically, Rod Rosenstein's office, and obviously, impeachment is personal. The way of that process is to start with holding somebody in contempt of Congress for failure to do what Congress expects to be done.

And then also, with regard to an impeachment effort, you would expect ordinarily following that, that there would be articles of impeachment, but hearings, and self-worth on a process where you really, kind of, get into the question about whether or not, the high bar of high crimes and misdemeanors is warranted.

I mean, a lot of this, to me, looks like Congress and the White House, to some degree, are unhappy with the Department of Justice and the office of the Deputy Attorney General but not specifically Rod Rosenstein himself. And you can't impeach the office. I mean, I think --

BARTIROMO: Right.

RAY: that's kind of what I see in this, it's like that, and I think that's what the speaker is referring to. That wouldn't meet the test. And it's understandable unhappiness but, you know, unhappiness doesn't mean that the high crimes and misdemeanors have been accomplished.

BARTIROMO: Of course. Now, one of -- one of the issues weighed in here, team in New York, one of the issues has been the fact that the Congressional Congress wants documents. And they feel that Rosenstein is telling the DOJ and people outside that we can't supply those documents.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a good point. Robert, your reaction?

I don't think that that's what the public expects to see. The public expects to see the institution of the Justice Department through the Deputy Attorney General's office to continually conclude this investigation properly, responsibly and in a cost-effective manner. You know, let's get it done.

FREEMAN: Yes, but, OK. But in terms of this contempt issue, we've seen a lot of these documents with black marker throughout. Do you think there is a case here and should Mr. Ryan be saying, impeachment is off the table, but, Rod Rosenstein is headed toward a contempt vote if he doesn't cough up more information?

RAY: Well, we don't even see that, right? I mean, he didn't say that. I don't expect--

FREEMAN: But should he say that?

RAY: Well, you know, what, I think -- it seems to me that both in terms of impeachment and even contempt, is an overreaction to what, Dagen, I think, was suggesting, is an overreaction to -- well, you are not happy about, you know, the level of reduction that goes on.

Look, nobody likes reductions because it's concealing from the public what, you know, Congress is, obviously, about, which is making sure that the American people are informed. But there are good and sufficient institutional reasons why sometimes the information is withheld from the public and the vehicle for doing that is redaction.

FREEMAN: Do you think all these redactions are justified?

RAY: I think it's a cooperative process. I mean, I don't always think that all reductions are justified. I mean, sort of, the same issue we get to with regard to withholding classified information. I mean, there are some legitimate, you know, need, to protect the privacy of information for the government to do what it is it does.

Same with regard to the integrity of an on-going investigation on reductions, you know, in that -- in that light and there's always a balance between the executive branch's interest and wanting to withhold information and Congress' interest in the oversight in making sure that the public is informed and people have a way to evaluate whether or not the Justice Department is acting appropriately.

And in that tension between the legislative and the executive branch, you know, there is room to wiggle and move around. But generally speaking, we don't overreact to that to say, wait a second, I don't like the level of reduction, so I'm going to hold you in contempt.

And, you know, even beyond that, I'm going to try to impeach you. I really don't think that's what this is about. I mean, these are the two institutions, kind of, jocking for position here.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RAY: And it's appropriate that that happens, that's in the public interest. But I do think the heavy hammer of impeachment is not warranted. And I also don't think it's politically wise and I think that's what the speaker was addressing.
