urn:contentItem:5SWT-RMT1-DXH2-600C-00000-00Deadly Northern California Wildfire Taking Down Everything In Its Path; ExxonMobil Shares Fall 2.2 Percent Premarket After Earnings Fall Short Of Estimates; 2Q GDP (1st Read): 4.1% (Act) Vs. 4.1% (Est); President Trump to Speak on Economy at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time From the White House2018-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:38:05ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTElliot Abrams; Anthony ChanNEWSFinancial072703cb.231Deadly Northern California Wildfire Taking Down Everything In Its Path; ExxonMobil Shares Fall 2.2 Percent Premarket After Earnings Fall Short Of Estimates; 2Q GDP (1st Read): 4.1% (Act) Vs. 4.1% (Est); President Trump to Speak on Economy at 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time From the White HouseMaria Bartiromo, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, Morgan Ortagus, Nicole Petallides, Karl Rove, Gerri Willis; Stuart Varney, Phil Flynn

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. Good Friday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. Happy Friday, and coming to you live this morning from nation's capital, where I will sit down for an exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence. You will see that on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on Fox News Channel this Sunday and here on "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" on Monday morning.

Happy Friday. It is Friday, July 27th. And your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. one the East Coast. The economy firing on all cylinders. The first look at the second quarter GDP, it's out in less than 30 minutes. It is expected to show growth in the economy of 4.1 percent. President Trump sounding of speaking in Iowa yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: The predictions from 3.8 to 5.3, right? I have been saying we're going to do all pretty well but nobody thought we were going to be this big. When I took over, those numbers were bad and they were heading in the wrong direction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Ahead of the report, futures are mixed. Take a look, Dow Industrials up 10 points, S&P 500 lower by half a point and the NASDAQ is up 3-3/4 points. Fractional moves across the board. Mixed performance yesterday on Wall Street. The Dow was up but others down, the Dow posting a triple digit gain while the NASDAQ and S&P 500 were in the red. In Europe this morning, gains across the board.

Take a look, money moving into equities in a big way, DAX Index up a half of a percent as is the FT-100 in London. In Asia overnight, markets were mostly higher with the exception of China, Shanghai Composite down a third of a percent. Investors are also watching earnings, Twitter earnings out last hour, decline in monthly users, taking the stock down this morning. It is down 16 percent on Twitter as investors are rethinking what the growth numbers are.

Really, for social media companies. We are waiting on ExxonMobil this morning. The first of the oil giants to report their second quarter this morning. We'll get the highlights from the floor of the New York Stock Exchange coming up with Exxon shares down almost one percent going into the numbers. Then there's this, finally coming home. North Korea handing over the remains of some U.S. soldiers killed in the line of duty during the Korean War.

We have the details as one of President Trump's promises becomes reality. The wildfire in Northern California turns deadly. The flames tearing through small towns, forcing thousands to flee their homes. The very latest developments coming up this morning straight ahead. All those stories coming up this morning and joining me to break it all down in New York, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell.

The Wall Street Journals' assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman, and national security analyst Morgan Ortagus. A lot happening this morning, guys. Good morning to you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning, Maria Bartiromo. I can't wait for that number of (INAUDIBLE) find out how fast this economy is growing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And it was Atlanta Fed, James Freeman, who predicted 4.8 percent. But did they walk that down to 4.5 percent recently? I know --

FREEMAN: Yes.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: They might even be slightly under four after that data we got Thursday, but --

BARTIROMO: Right, right.

FREEMAN: But still very optimistic and, you know, more good news, this rising household formation. That was kind of a story of the Obama years was kids living in parents' basements waiting for the opportunity to move out so that that surge I think is very hopeful sign that we turn the corner and maybe some of those millennials who everyone says, believe in socialism will now see some of the benefits of free markets.

BARTIROMO: What do you think, Morgan?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: I think certainly, anyone running us, a Democratic socialist, this number today is not going to help the cause, you know, which is a good thing. We can just look as far as south as Venezuela to see what socialism does in our hemisphere. So, it's going to be a good number today and it's going to help the White House continue to focus on jobs.

And the people that elected Donald Trump, that care about getting their jobs back, they care about economy.

BARTIROMO: And we're going to get the White House reaction firsthand. I'm here in Washington this morning for an exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence that will air this weekend on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES," on Fox News at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will have -- plus more of that interview of my sit down on Monday morning right here on "MORNINGS WITH MARIA" beginning 6:00 a.m. Eastern.

Don't miss my interview with the Vice President, coming out. Coming up on the program. We have this breaking news, we want to get out right now. Exxon earnings are out. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the details. And Nick, ExxonMobil shares were down going into the quarter.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes. And you know what, it's now the third quarter of weakness for Exxon. A big miss on earnings per share, Maria. You could see it's now down 1.8 percent, 92 cents versus a buck 27. Revenue did come in and beat 73.5 versus 72.5. The CEOs saying second quarter results were primarily impacted by significantly scheduled maintenance undertaken to support operational integrity.

But the big picture here is that it's a miss, again. Last quarter the profit missed on the estimates on refining and chemical woes. So again, another miss for Exxon, Dow component too. So we'll watch for that. But for the most part, we've seen a lot of beats, 72 percent have beaten on revenue and 84 percent have beaten on earnings per share thus far. That being said, let's also take a look at Twitter which this morning you noted, the active users fell by a million.

So that really surprised Wall Street because they were expecting a million gain in users. So, with that move to the downside, the stock has been down about 16 percent. And take a look at Facebook which had the biggest fall ever since its 2012 IPO. It's the biggest loss ever for a company over 100 billion lost in one day. Zuckerberg losses 16 billion of his own money and so you can see the stock is coming back by one percent.

But we have a discussion about this yesterday, some people want to consider buying this back and others don't want to touch it concerned about management and the company overall, Maria. And I will leave with you this, Jeffrey Frankel just came over from Stuart Frankel. You know him well and basically continues to say, there is no better place to buy them in the U.S., and he reiterated equity is the place to go.

The volatility has been wild, what an exciting week it has been and the value players have been picking them and liquidating in them throughout the day. We had a wild close yesterday too on some very heavy volume. Maria?

BARTIROMO: Yes. I'm just scratching my head, how do you have a miss when oil prices are where they are. We're going to take a look at that, Nic. Thank you so much as you see, that stock is lower. The GDP report less than 30 minutes away. That will likely set the tone for markets but because of the ExxonMobil numbers, things have come in a bit for futures. We're expecting a higher opening but not where we were earlier.

President Trump touted the strength of the economy and alluded to the strong GDP number yesterday.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We've never seen anything like going on right now. We're going to have very big numbers announced tomorrow. I don't know what they are but a lot of big predictions, I think they're going to be to be terrific. You know, we took over, it was really low and it was heading lower, a lot lower and was going to be there fast and great things have happened.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now to talk more about that, Fox News contributor, former senior adviser for President George W. Bush, Karl Rove. Karl, good to see you, my friend.

KARL ROVE, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning. And look, I want to get started on a positive note. I'm willing to contribute $5.00 to the Zuckerberg relief fund. Make sure the lad gets a nice lunch today. So, five bucks, count me in.

BARTIROMO: Ohm goodness. Listen, he is still a multibillionaire, Karl, so let's not go crazy on this upset for Facebook stock, but what's your take in -- I want to ask you about that because the -- your reaction to what we're seeing in terms of the censoring of conservative ideas on Twitter, on Facebook and this backlash that these companies are now facing.

ROVE: Well, I think that's a part of the story. The bigger part of the story is the vulnerability of our tech companies. These tech companies have grown so fast, the expectations are so high, they've got so many things that they have to deal with, whether it's like concerns on Twitter about Conservatives being sort of dislodged and pushed to the side or Facebook where the question is your privacy rights.

So, all of these, many issues that they face I think demonstrated the vulnerability of this once thought invulnerable big tech companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And we'll see if there's a heavier government hand in terms of regulation as a result of some of this. They're going to be going testifying in front of the Senate, Sheryl Sandberg and others, so we'll watch that. But let me ask you about the GDP and the economy, Karl because when President comments on economic data, before it's actually released, it's usually an indicator of the strong report. What are you expecting?

ROVE: Well, he doesn't know what the number is. When he talked yesterday in Granite City, I want to be clear, he had not yet been informed, he was probably informed maybe sometime this morning, maybe sometime late last night. But Presidents are not supposed to talk about that number publicly once they're given it. So my suspicion is he was looking at the same day that we've all been looking at.

April, May and June, capital investment, investment in capital goods excluding aircraft up dramatically, April, May, June, retail numbers up significantly. So this is going to be the first GDP number that's going to be actually have all of the regulatory reform baked in and see the beginning of the impact of the tax reform measure. So, we've seen estimates from three to five, the consensus appears to be just around four, just slightly north of four.

And it's going to be a very good number. Ironically, I will tell you politically this is a -- you can't just bask in the glory of the moment. I've been through a couple of these moments in the White House myself and there's an ironic thing, is when the economy is really going good, they pay momentary attention to good news like this and then they sort of say, well, the economy is doing good. I'm on the other things.

So the administration needs to not only sort of say, well, look at the good results of our policies, but all incidentally, here are some additional things we want to do to keep our economy going strong because there is a -- there is a -- real -- you know, temptation by ordinary people to say, I'm banking that the economy is good, now I'm looking on other things that concern me.

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes. But that's the thing, I mean, we talk about this every morning and that is trade. And we are wondering if these tariffs and trade are going to have an impact on this number, Karl.

ROVE: Well, about in fact, the people over the American Action Network say one thing might be baked into these numbers is people -- companies were afraid of the impact of tariffs so they forward ordered, they said, OK, I'm going to need more steel and aluminum, so before that tariff gets put in on steel and aluminum, I'm going to preorder it. There are things that might be coming from China.

Where I want to get ahead of the tariffs so that I get these -- so there may be some and we'll see that in the inventory numbers but, yes, there are some instability there. The president this week with the E.U., they already change (INAUDIBLE) foe, now we're going to be allies together in reducing tariffs and tariffs barriers, non-tariff barriers and we're going to be also I thought largely passed over in public comment but really important.

The E.U. and the United States are going to be working together at the two in order to rein in China's trade abuses. So good news on that front but you're right, this number, the last quarter, there have been, you know, this was the quarter of talk about tariff wars and trade wars and that's going to be reflected maybe to the good in people pre-ordering but also reflected in the ongoing with people being concerned about what the economy is going to look like in the months ahead.

BARTIROMO: Yes. But, look, Dagen has pointed this out correctly, like the Wall Street Journal editorial board, like 24 lawmakers who are up in arms and have been yesterday that these trade -- these tariffs are cutting into growth. Correct, Dagen?

MCDOWELL: They are. Karl, when you have the President on the -- essentially at a campaign rally as he was yesterday bragging about the steel industry coming back. I can't help but think what about all the industries that will be hurt by the higher price of steel, small businesses far and wide, people who's costs have gone up, their supply chains have been disrupted whether they make kegs of beer or nails or even school lockers.

And then you've seen in these earnings reports this week but Ford and General Motors came out and talked about how much that they have been hurt by the higher costs.

ROVE: Sure.

MCDOWELL: Each day and the commodity prices have shaved $300 million from their second quarter results. Even Coca-Cola is raising prices. So politically, you need to be careful about -- crone about one industry and then basically ignoring all the ones that are -- basically not your favorite business.

ROVE: Yes. Well, look, I couldn't agree more. If somebody has to pay that tariff, the tariff is not being paid by the people abroad, it's being paid by us here, largely in the form of higher costs and missed opportunities and lost jobs. If you're going to raise the price or something by 25 percent which is what has happened with steel, there are going to be some victims of it. Same with A.G. products.

The President talked yesterday about how the E.U. is going to buy a bunch of soybeans. Well, the markets have not yet reflected that, because the cost for soybeans is down. Since the Chinese canceled the contracts, soybean prices have plummeted, so have pork prices which when the Chinese retaliated on us by placing tariffs on pork. So I'm with you, that's why - - maybe I'm hanging on the good news more than I should.

But the President has finally revealed he had three choices, he sounded sometimes like a mercantilist, there's no good trade deal unless you buy more from us than we buy from you. Sometimes he sounded like a rules based trader, you know, everybody ought to abide by the rules but this week he sounded like a free trader and we got a -- all tariffs and obstacles to trade to zero and frankly, I like that and it's going to be --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We'll see if it's fixed. We'll see if it's fixed, Karl.

ROVE: -- in a trade deficit today with Nicaragua.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you, sir. Thank you so much.

ROVE: Why? Because they grow bananas and we don't.

BARTIROMO: We will see if it's fixed. Stay with us. We'll brining you the first reading of the second quarter GDP in under 20 minutes. 15 minutes form now. Back in a minute.

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back to MORNINGS WITH MARIA. I'm Gerri Willis with your headlines. Wildfires raging through Northern California turning deadly. The fire near Redding, California killing a bulldozer operator as he fought to combat the blaze. Officials say the man was quickly surrounded by flames and unable to escape.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRETT GOUVEA, CAL FIRE INCIDENT COMMANDER CHIEF: we mourn the loss, we also battle the fire that is moving extremely quickly and erratically into Western Redding.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WILLIS: Sad story. At least three firefighters and several residents have also been injured in the fire which started on Monday and it since tripled in size. Governor Jerry Brown has declared a state of emergency in Redding and surrounding Shasta County. And earnings a big story today. Results from Dow component, ExxonMobil coming in just minutes ago. The company reporting a big miss on earnings per share.

Mainly due to what Exxon is calling significant rescheduled maintenance. Revenue top expectations. ExxonMobil stock under pressure in the premarket, Merck though, another Dow component is out with better-than- expected earnings. Sales of the company's cancer drug, you've heard of it, Keytruda nearly doubling. Merck also raised its profit outlook for the full year, even so the stock slightly lower in the premarket.

But it is a different story for Colgate-Palmolive. The company's latest quarterly sales missed the street forecast. The sales in Latin America falling seven percent from a year ago. Colgate shares are sharply lower ahead of the opening bell.

Here's my favorite story today. Krispy Kreme donuts marking 81st birthday with a special deal for today only. Krispy Kreme is selling a dozen glazed donuts for a dollar. That's my favorite kind. The offer is available at all Krispy Kreme locations in the U.S. and Canada, also going on sales today are Krispy Kreme's limited edition, confetti donuts. It's birthday cake-flavored dough mixed with confetti sprinkles.

Covered in the company's classic glaze before being topped off with even more sprinkles because you can't have enough. Dagen, here is my dollar, I got to get going and get over there.

MCDOWELL: Get over there. Thank you so much, Gerri.

WILLIS: You're welcome.

MCDOWELL: I want to wish the most special woman in my life a very happy birthday. My mama. There she is with my dad, her partner in crime since she was like 13 years of age. My mother turned 80 today. She will kill me for that. But this woman is the embodiment of grace and strength, wisdom, devotion and in the last four years since she's been battling stage four lung cancer, she is the epitome of courage.

She is an icon to me and so many people. I love with you all my heart, mama. That fellow, my daddy turns 82 on Sunday. So they look pretty good for 80 and 82. Go McDowells. And by the way, here's a lot of love to anybody battling cancer today. I think about, you know, say prayers for you every single day, them and their families.

Coming up. We are awaiting the first reading of second quarter GDP due out in 10 minutes exactly. Economist expecting growth, north of four percent, 4.1 percent? Will we see a five? You have to. Stay with us to find out. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Protecting America's vote. President Trump gearing up for a meeting today of the National Security Council on election security. A session that could include a discussion of possible Russian interference in November's midterm elections. Joining us right now is the former deputy national security adviser under George W. Bush and former National Security Council senior director for Near East and North African Affairs, Elliott Abrams.

Elliot, good to see you this morning. Thanks so much for joining us.

ELLIOT ABRAMS, FORMER SENIOR DIRECTOR, NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL: Glad to be here.

MCDOWELL: You watched this for a long time, Elliot. So, I want to get your take first on how long we have been watching Russia undermine the west?

ABRAMS: You know, it isn't really that long that we've watched them under the line elections. Obviously go back to the Cold War, they were the main enemy in Cold War. Really since World War II. What we used to think of election security as, you know, fraud. People in the cemeteries, voting. This is new. This notion that voting is part of the critical infrastructure like the banks and the power plants subject to hacking by an enemy government abroad.

That's new and that really is only since 2016.

BARTIROMO: Wow. So Russian hackers already attempted to interfere in the 2018 midterms targeting vulnerable Democratic Senator Claire McCaskill. The Daily Beast is reporting on this attempted August 2017 hack with Senator McCaskill issuing a statement and here's what she said yesterday. Russia continues to engage in cyberwarfare against our democracy. While this attack was not successful it is outrageous that they think they can get away with this.

I will not be intimidated, I've said it before and I will say it again, Putin is a thug and is a bully. So do politicians need to make election security a higher priority for their staff in terms of training going into the midterms?

ABRAMS: They do. They really do. You know, the problem is we don't have one election, we have 50-state elections that we have in this country, more than 3,000 counties. So election security is really hard to do and hard to coordinate. And we are not making the Russians pay a price for this. You know, now we know about the Claire McCaskill hack by Russia, so what happens? Are there sanctions? Is there a punishment or you know they try again?

Until we impose some costs, we just have to assume the Russians will keep trying it every level of government.

BARTIROMO: So that's what we need to do. Come back with some kind of punishment because is there anything we can do to actually stop it before they start?

ABRAMS: Yes. There are ways. I mean, the -- there needs to be are better coordination between CIA, FBI, Homeland Security and the people who are actually administering elections, you know, the state election boards are not Federal. There's 50 of them, and they're the ones that really need to have the improved security and many of them are not yet up to the about task.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Makes sense. All right. We'll keep watching that. Thanks very much for weighing in on this important issue.

ABRAMS: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Elliot Abrams joining us. Coming up. We are waiting the first reading of second quarter GDO. The number out in three minutes' time right after this break. Catch it right here. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. I'm Maria Bartiromo come to you live from Washington, D.C. this morning where I will interview Vice President Mike Pence later today. You'll see that exclusive interview on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on the Fox News Channel this Sunday and right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA on Monday. Join me for the White House reaction to the GDP number.

We are getting a first look at the second quarter GDP out any second in about 10 seconds time. We will have the number. The expectations call for growth of 4.1 percent. Let's take a look at futures right before this number hits the tape. It's about to hit and as we see, markets right now are lover with Dow industrials down seven points and the S&P down a fraction but the NASDAQ has reversed and it is actually up.

J.P. Morgan managing director and chief economist Anthony Chan will join us right now to talk more about it. 4.1 percent is the number, Anthony, right in line with expectations. Good to see you this morning, your reaction to the GDP, 4.1 percent growth.

ANTHONY CHAN, MANAGING DIRECTOR AND CHIEF ECONOMIST, J.P. MORGAN: I think that's a great number, it really shows that consumers are getting energized, getting a little bit more consumer confidence. We'll have to look at the details. Obviously, the net exports are going to be strong, a lot of countries trying to sort of get a jump-start ahead of the tariffs so that was boosted a little bit there, then we'll have to look at the inventory to see what happens to the next quarter.

BARTIROMO: So, you want to look at inventories. What about business spending? Is that a component that you are focused on in terms of giving us a window of where we head next? As you see, markets have turned around and now we're looking at a gain on the -- well, it's back-and-forth so it's unchanged right now. But tell us what's most important about this number right now, Anthony?

CHAN: I think the important thing is to look at these things, not only just in a given quarter but certainly over multiple quarters. I think that certainly the instant expensing of business investment will boost capital spending, and that will in turn boost productivity growth as you know, Maria, that has been one of the things that has held down economic growth, and now giving a shot in the arm to encourage businesses investment, will definitely give a shot in the arm to productivity, and I think that will help elevate the growth rates for real GDP moving forward.

BARTIROMO: And Dagen, you've got details now as we're looking and zeroing in on this number, what strikes you about this 4.1 percent report?

MCDOWELL: Well, one thing that we should note is the fact that the estimates by a lot of economists after the durable goods report yesterday started coming down. That Atlanta Fed number that we watch so closely had been lowered to 3.8 percent, so this number does come in higher than that. And we had other economists that were projecting close to five percent, they had lowered it to about 4-1/2 percent, but again, this is still such a solid number. This is the first time that we've gotten growth for any quarter before four percent since the third-quarter of 2014. So, nearly four years. It's been that long since we've seen a four in front of quarterly growth. That's a very -- that's something very important to note.

BARTIROMO: I just want to also point out that the first-quarter GDP is being revised upward, it was two percent, now it's 2.2 percent, a revision on the first-quarter GDP, Anthony Chan, we were looking at a good quarter as it was but now they're saying first-quarter GDP revised upward.

CHAN: That certainly helps the yearly numbers, as you know, Maria. This was a report that was going to revise all the way going backwards. So, it's not just one calendar quarter but it's a multiple number of quarters that are going to be revised, that gives you a very good idea of where the economy is going to go because the first quarter had been originally revised down now it's coming back. That will give you a little bit of a boost. It looks like this year we're going to come really, really close to about a three percent growth when all is said and done if this trend continues.

BARTIROMO: That's going to be the first time in a long time, James Freeman, for three percent.

FREEMAN: Yes, kaboom, this is huge news. This is now kind of officially the end of the new normal two percent sluggish growth era. This is 12 months of better than three percent growth, this is what the White House was hoping for, what everyone was hoping for, and we -- you know, we talked about these numbers, this is more jobs, more opportunity for people in this country, and millions of people who look for work within the last few years, but maybe weren't looking this year, we know they could rejoin the labor force, maybe they will now. It's just fantastic news to see that we've turned a corner.

BARTIROMO: Well -- yes, go ahead, Anthony.

CHAN: And one thing, Maria, that's really important about this number is that it's real in the sense that consumer spending coming in so strong, giving you a four percent number, you can look at all the components and quibble about them, but when you see consumer spending this strong, that's impressive.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a really important point, because the consumer has been debatable, right? I mean, earlier in the year, we were looking at a consumer that perhaps was saving more money than they were actually spending. Are you saying that's changed?

CHAN: I think it has in the sense that in the first quarter, you got only about a half a percent growth in consumer spending, that's two-thirds of the overall economy. Remember that confidence on the part of the consumers is what drives this economic growth. And then, when businesses see the consumers are excited, guess what, they're even more encouraged to spend more and that in turn boosts productivity and boost the underlying growth trend of the overall economy. So, I always look to see what consumers are doing because that drives the future path of real GDP.

BARTIROMO: Of course, two-thirds of economic growth consumer activity. Dagen, how do you see it?

MCDOWELL: Trade played a big part of this second-quarter number, net exports added more than one percentage point to the 4.1 percent GDP growth that we got, 1.06 percentage points there. Some of that would have been buying by overseas of trading partners of soybeans ahead of these tariffs, these retaliatory tariffs that went into effect in the beginning of July. That was after the end of the second quarter. So, we're going to have to wait for the third-quarter GDP to really find out the impact of the -- this trade fight as it picked up steam moving into the month of July. So again, it was maybe buying that was pulled forward into the second quarter, and then that will be buying that isn't present in the third. I would just leave it at that.

BARTIROMO: Yes. The important point, Morgan Ortagus, the president likes to say economic security is national security and vice versa.

ORTAGUS: Yes, absolutely, I mean, this is exactly what he ran on, this is what he pledged to the American people that if you don't elect a politician, if you elect someone from the business community, Maria, that we're going to get exceptional growth. And this is what Republicans said, you know, over the past eight years, sure, the economy grew, but very marginally. We did got out of the great recession. But when you unleash the powers of the business community, it's not just about tax reform, it's also about -- and you've talked so much on your show, Maria, about the expansive regulatory reform that's gone on. And so, businesses feel on fire again. I think that this number -- it's important for the economy, it's a huge blow to Democrat socialists, but I think more importantly, putting the politics aside, it's good for America, it's good for mom and pop shops, it's good for corporations. This is a great day for the Trump presidency.

BARTIROMO: What do you look for next, Anthony Chan, in terms of another window into where we're going? The administration is talking about Tax Plan 2.0, it's questionable whether or not that passes in the Senate right before the election, the midterm election, of course, but do you see more stimulus coming? What are you going to be focused on post this GDP number?

CHAN: Well, one of the things that many people are not talking about is that when you look at employment, for example, you've been seeing more and more people coming from out of the labor force into the labor force. So, a lot of the new jobs that are being created, not so much from people that are unemployed because that pool is so small, but people that are being pulled out of an area that was people that were not in the labor force. So, I look for that to continue to move forward and I look for confidence to continue to support the overall economy. So, those things, I think, are in themselves quite good in this form of stimulus. And then, I'm hopeful that we'll get some more positive progress on the trade front. We've got some good news yesterday from Europe, maybe that will spread into other parts of the world, and that will even give more business confidence, so that this growth and momentum continues a bit further.

BARTIROMO: Was this all priced in, guys? Anybody surprised that we're not seeing much of a market reaction, in fact, the Dow Industrials down now 28 points?

FREEMAN: Well, look, I think people were expecting a blowout quarter.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: The President's remarks, yes, he was talking about private estimates, but you've heard the President and others. I think he even mentioned who knows we may be get close to five. So --

BARTIROMO: Right.

FREEMAN: -- people were expecting this one would be great. I think now obviously, it'd be hard to repeat this next time, but I think there's a reason to think, we've talked about these are really systemic changes in terms of tax and regulation that are not one-quarter stories, I think there's reason to think this growth continues.

BARTIROMO: Yes, because there's that runway. Dagen, yes?

MCDOWELL: In optimism, we're looking at the 10-year yield, it is below three percent. There was actually a worry that you would see that 10-year yield go back above three percent. So again, that's taken -- this is just -- it's just hot enough to keep people from really dumping their treasuries here, worried about much faster growth, and a couple of things to note about the Dow that Intel and ExxonMobil are going to shave about 40 points off the Dow Jones Industrial Average. So, that's really just a reaction particularly to Exxon's earnings which were a miss, rather than a reaction to this extremely healthy growth number on the economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point, absolutely. Anthony, there is a narrative going on that the consumer slows down quite a bit, going into 2019, going into 2020 as a result of a number of things, not to, you know, at least of which is the Federal Reserve. The Feds raising interest rates, that may very well cut into -- cut into growth. Your thoughts on where this economy heads after '18, and this robust performance.

CHAN: Well, I think at some point, the economy has to rest if it doesn't get re-energized, just from quarter to quarter, it's simply. Like for example, this quarter, one of the things that held up growth even though it's an impressive 4.1 percent was the change in inventories, it subtracted basically one percent off economic growth. That's not bad news, Maria, because that means that next quarter, if this momentum continues, you've got to build those inventories, so will add to economic growth. So, even though we came in a little bit weaker than some people may have thought, maybe a little bit over 4.2 or 4.3, but you basically are taking some -- you're going to give some back next quarter.

But in terms of what moves us forward, I think that we need to see a business sentiment picking up. And to the extent that we're making some progress on international trade issues, that will be, I think, the catalyst to give us that extra boost over the next couple of calendar quarters. But, Maria, the bottom line is this economic expansion now is the second longest basically in the history of the United States. So, at some point, it will have to rest. The question is, is it going to be a soft landing or is it going to be a hard landing, but there are going to be some slowdown at some point, and we think 2020 is a possibility.

BARTIROMO: So, the Fed has pencilled in two more rate hikes this year, three rate hikes in 2019, this report basically gives you a shoo-in that the Fed continues raising rates, right?

CHAN: There is no doubt that the Fed will continue to raise rates, but remember, the Fed is not tone deaf, if they see any sort of a slowdown, they're not going to exacerbate it, they will in fact try to pause. So, I'm confident that the Fed will do the right thing, and in fact, they've gotten some encouragement from comments made by the President to do the right thing and be a bit more cautious.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Guys, what do you think about the trade number playing a big role in the second-quarter's growth? Dagen, you mentioned exports adding 1.06 percentage points to the quarter's 4.1 percent GDP growth rate, exports up as well, strong.

MCDOWELL: Indeed, a lot of that was the Commerce Department reported that soybean exports did surge in the second quarter, again, ahead of those tariffs going on those retaliatory tariffs from China, and then our tariffs on imported -- with 34 billion in imported Chinese good that first week in the month of July, that will be -- that will be critical. How do we offset any drop in our exports in the current quarter? But again, to just focus on the health of the U.S. economy, this is -- we're looking at soybeans. Soybeans are actually up a little bit today. But if you look at the broad economy, I think that the tariff truce, the de-escalation of tensions that we found out from -- with Europe this week is really helping, it comes at a critical time that if you could actually pick up exports into Europe in the month of August and September, that will be much-needed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And how about the personal savings rate -- it's now at 6.8 percent, Anthony, that's in the second quarter, it's down from 7.2 percent in the first quarter, so just what we were just talking about, where consumers were saving a lot of their tax gains in the first quarter, they spent that money in this quarter.

CHAN: Maria, that's again, another sign of confidence. Remember, the 6.8 percent number is still high, I think it could go a little bit lower, I would not be uncomfortable if it moves a little bit lower and that means the consumer spending, but that can only happen when consumers feel a little bit more confident about the future. And we have an opportunity for that.

BARTIROMO: All right, big news. Anthony, great to see you, thank so much for weighing in this morning.

CHAN: Pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Anthony Chan, J.P. Morgan. Remember to stay tuned for my exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence. It will air this weekend on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on Fox News at 10:00 a.m. Eastern. We will have more of that sit-down on Monday morning right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA, beginning at 6:00 a.m. Eastern. Join me for the White House's reaction when I sit down with Vice President Mike Pence.

First though, coming up, Stuart Varney is weighing in on the first reading of the second-quarter GDP. We'll get Stuart's thoughts, coming up. And then big oil reporting quarterly results below estimates, Chevron and Exxon under pressure this morning. Take a look, Exxon is down four percent, Chevron is down almost three percent. These are Dow components, that's the problem in the Dow, as you just heard. Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We're watching oil prices this morning. We just got the GDP number out. It is 4.1 percent, pretty much in line with lowered expectations. We're also watching the price of oil here, down a fraction, back below $70.00 a barrel.

Phil Flynn is joining us right now to talk more about that. He's from The PRICE of Futures Group, Phil, good to see you this morning.

PHIL FLYNN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CONTRIBUTOR: Good morning, Maria. It's great to be here, but not a big day for oil today. It's kind of a small day, at least, for ExxonMobil.

BARTIROMO: Yes. I mean, we're looking at oil at $70.00 a barrel, pretty much. And you got ExxonMobil reporting a miss in its earnings, explain?

FLYNN: It really is -- and years ago, ExxonMobil cut back capital spending probably way too much. And that they made some very bad decisions when it came on that. Their actual production was the lowest level expense since 2008, and that isn't good when oil prices are going back up.

Now, they have increased their capital spending by a dramatic amount, but it might be too little too late in the short term to take advantage of these high prices. I think ExxonMobil made some bad decisions and that's what it's showing up on the earnings.

Now, they have made some big investments in the Permian Basin and some other areas, to get that production up. But, it's not going to show up in the earnings for a period of time.

BARTIROMO: So, do you think this is the right reaction? ExxonMobil shares down almost five percent this morning. That's one of the issues holding back the Dow Industrials.

FLYNN: I think, initially, based off this shock value, it is, but ExxonMobil is a great stock. I own it in my own portfolios. I would use this as a long term buying opportunity, because, the bottom line is, is that U.S. energy is going to come back in a big way. This is going to be a major factor in this country. I think ExxonMobil is starting to get their act together.

They're going to be focusing more on production, more on the refining end, and I think that's why they are going to do so good. Chevron, on the other hand, they did a little better because they have been focusing on the refining that did much, much better, a lot smarter, made some better decisions.

And that is why they're doing a little bit better. So, maybe, hopefully, Chevron can lead back ExxonMobil today.

BARTIROMO: And yet, that stock is also down about two percent on Chevron. Look, we heard a lot about the boom in U.S. energy capacity, this week. President Trump's agreement with Jean-Claude Juncker of the European Commission, promising to boost liquid natural gas exports to Europe. Here's what Energy Secretary Rick Perry told me about that yesterday on this program.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

RICK PERRY, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF ENERGY: They know that we have this extraordinary supply of what's happened in the energy sector is phenomenal from the standpoint of production of liquefied natural gas.

And it has multiple impacts, obviously, for National Security, in America, the idea that we're being able to supply our own gas and oil supply. But, also, to go to our allies, and that was the message the President had for the E.U.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, Flynn, your reaction?

FLYNN: Finally, an energy secretary that gets it, and big energy. And I was amazed to see after your interview yesterday, all the people that were kind of downplaying President Trump and Rick Perry's movement to Europe with L&G, because, really, that is our future.

L&G is going to make the U.S. an economic and energy powerhouse in the future. Europe is starting to get that right now. Europe's actual production of natural gas is plunging. They're going to become more reliant and other people to provide their natural gas and that U.S. should be first in line.

BARTIROMO: All right, Phil, good to see you this morning, thanks very much, Phil Flynn. We'll be right back, a lot more to come.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The first read on second quarter GDP is out. It is in line with the economists' expectations, 4.1 percent growth is what we saw in the second quarter. Markets this morning have been back-and-forth.

Not a major reaction, but certainly, back-and-forth negative, positive territory. We're looking at the Dow up seven points, the NASDAQ up 22-1/2.

We have breaking news right now, President Trump will speak about the economy, this morning, at 9:30 a.m. Eastern, of course, Fox Business Network will have full coverage. And we will take you to the White House, live, when the President makes those comments and gives his reaction to this GDP number.

Look, we've got to talk earnings, team. So, the GDP number, obviously, very strong, on a consumer level, on a business spending level, but then there's Twitter, there's ExxonMobil, there's Facebook. What's your takeaway?

MCDOWELL: Let's talk about Amazon, since that's some of the good news this morning. As you pointed out Exxon's profit misses pulling the Dow down a little bit or holding it back with this great reading on the economy, best in almost four years.

But Amazon reported a profit. This used to be a company, just a couple years ago, that would lose money. But because of these additional businesses like the Whole Foods acquisition, because of its growth, in cloud computing, which you talked to Satya Nadella about, in Microsoft, a competitor of Amazon, the stock's up four percent in premarket trading.

Amazon made more than $2-1/2 billion in the most recent quarter. So this is a -- this is a standout report from Amazon. And one worth noting particularly with what happened with its operating margin is at 5.6 percent. That's the highest rate in over a decade for Amazon.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and it's certainly a standout when you look at the Twitter report, and when you look at Facebook, Twitter shares this morning, was sliding. Revenue beat expectations, but the company's monthly users declined. James, take a look at this reaction, down better than 11 percent, as people get out of Twitter this morning.

FREEMAN: Yes. You wonder why people are a little less eager to use these services. Maybe it's political concern, maybe they don't want their data being abused, we'll see. It's a first time, really. It's the first quarter that these concerns are showing up in the numbers, as our colleague, Dagen, predicted they would.

But, overall, this is a greet earning season and I think some of these problems, Exxon, Facebook, et cetera, are specific to those companies. This is a fantastic economic report, as well.

We were talking about the investment, wasn't as great as the first quarter, but 7.3 percent growth in non-residential fixed investments, spending by businesses, the tax cuts on corporate income is working exactly as planned.

BARTIROMO: That is big. That is a big number. And you got to also point to the rollback in regulations for that. Let's look at a quick break, everybody, and then we'll have some final thoughts. Don't forget to stay tuned for my exclusive interview with Vice President Mike Pence, airing this weekend on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on Fox News at 10:00 a.m. Eastern, Sunday.

We'll have more of my sit-down on Monday morning right here, MORNINGS WITH MARIA, beginning at 6:00 to 9:00 a.m. Eastern, back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Great show today, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, Morgan Ortagus, great to see you.

MCDOWELL: Love you.

FREEMAN: Good to be here.

ORTAGUS: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will see you soon. Have a great weekend, everybody, thanks for joining us. That will do it for us. Join me on Sunday for Vice President Mike Pence. Here's Stuart Varney in Varney & Company. Stuart, take it away.

<xhtml:span id="h6" class="hits-fragment" xmlns:xhtml="http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml">... you've talked so much on your show, Maria, about the expansive <xhtml:span class="hit">regulatory</xhtml:span> reform that's gone on. And so, businesses feel on fire again. ...</xhtml:span>
